meaning_mnemonic: You think you see some legs behind those bars. Who gets put behind bars? Only <radical>criminal</radical>s. This criminal is pretty tall, since you only see his legs behind there.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <radical>comfort</radical>.
There are a bunch of cages boiling. But you look inside the cages and there... there's <radical>nothing</radical>. You boiled whatever was in there down to nothing!

This is the samurai radical on top of the mouth radical. If you get to hear what a samurai says, you'll have really <radical>good luck</radical>. Samurai are pretty hard to find nowadays, which is probably why my luck has been so bad...

You lost seven toes on a cliff, but you consider yourself lucky considering you got them taken off by the cliff <radical>tiger</radical> that lives in the area. Imagine a tiger taking your seven toes as you hang off the edge of a cliff if it helps. Exciting! (And also painful!)
The flowery paragraph isn't just regular writing. It's flowery, which makes it a <radical>poem</radical>.

This radical is made up of horns and older brother. But those aren't really horns, they're a part of your older brother's new <radical>guard</radical> uniform. He's a guard now, of a bank or a museum. You don't know which, but you know he stands around a lot in his uniform now.
The "soil mouth" is the mouth that eats the soil. The animal that does this best is the <radical>worm</radical>. Nom nom nom.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means <radical>festival</radical>.

A <radical>criminal</radical>'s <radical>heart</radical> will always be <kanji>sad</kanji>. No one chooses a life of crime if they're happy. And even if they seem like they're doing fine on the outside, deep down they're really sad.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>sad</kanji> feelings fill the criminal's body with <reading>he</reading>at (ひ). This heat spreads and radiates out. If you walk next to them on the street, you'll feel the sad heat floating by you.

meaning_mnemonic: If there is a <radical>drum</radical> in your <radical>mouth</radical> it's time to <kanji>rejoice</kanji>! And because of your mouth drum your rejoicing will be loud and booming!
reading_mnemonic: You loudly <kanji>rejoice</kanji> for a while when suddenly someone runs over and shoves a <reading>key</reading> (き) in your mouth, locking it shut. You can't rejoice anymore! You need that key to unlock your mouth!

meaning_mnemonic:
The <radical>original</radical> radical and the <kanji>original</kanji> kanji are the same!

This kanji can also mean <kanji>field</kanji>, probably because that's what everything originally looked like before humans: just a bunch of fields.
reading_mnemonic: The <kanji>original</kanji> Japanese hero was <reading>Gen</reading>ji (げん), from "The Tale of Genji."

meaning_mnemonic: If you take a <radical>thread</radical> and plant a <radical>rice paddy</radical> on it, the rice paddy is going to be extremely <kanji>thin</kanji>, but also <kanji>detailed</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>thin</kanji> rice paddy is for your <reading>cy</reading>borg (さい). You gave your cyborg a very thin human stomach, so it can only digest one thin line of rice at a time.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Flowers</radical> can be used for <radical>comfort</radical>, but also for <kanji>medicine</kanji>. Sure, it’s a comfort to smell flowers because they smell nice, but one can also use them as medicine to heal people.
reading_mnemonic: The best way to transport all the <kanji>medicine</kanji> on land is with a <reading>yak</reading> (やく). Yaks are big, strong, and very capable of transporting flower medicine like these.

meaning_mnemonic: You're all by your lonesome <radical>self</radical> and have to check each <radical>rice paddy</radical> you own, all <radical>twenty</radical> of them! Luckily, you have a very astute <kanji>nose</kanji>, allowing you to quickly assess the state of your twenty rice paddies all by yourself.
reading_mnemonic: As you're about to finish checking your paddies, your <kanji>nose</kanji> picks up an additional smell: It's <reading>Hannah</reading>, bringing you a bunch of <reading>花</reading> (はな)!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>leader</radical> of the <radical>shellfish</radical> has a <radical>knife</radical> in its <kanji>side</kanji>. It's fine though, don't worry, it's just a reminder that he won the great shellfish war back when they were trying to choose the new leader.
reading_mnemonic: Because of this knife in his <kanji>side</kanji>, he can't pronounce certain words correctly. The most obvious one is when he says <reading>川</reading> (かわ), but it comes out of the side of his mouth as がわ.

meaning_mnemonic: When you swing your <radical>axe</radical>, the <radical>ground</radical> ends up covered in <radical>fins</radical>, because you're a <kanji>soldier</kanji>. Only a skilled axe soldier could make such precise cuts as to de-fin a bunch of fish like that.
reading_mnemonic: Uh-oh, it looks like this axe <kanji>soldier</kanji> was so excited about chopping the fins off his fish that he didn't think about how he was going to cook them. The only thing nearby to light on fire is a bale of <reading>hay</reading> (へい). Well, it's not the best thing, but at least it will get these fish cooked.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>Viking</radical> will empty his <radical>mouth</radical> of all its <radical>dirt</radical> in the great <kanji>hall</kanji>. They all get together in some kind of <kanji>public chamber</kanji> and dish all the dirt (literal and figurative) that they've got.
reading_mnemonic: While the Vikings gather to spill the dirt in their <kanji>hall</kanji>, they also stuff their faces with <reading>dou</reading>ghnuts (どう). Ah yes, Vikings love to eat doughnuts when they talk trash.

meaning_mnemonic: In the <radical>dirt</radical>, there's a <radical>gun</radical>. Its <radical>mouth</radical> points toward a <radical>plate</radical>. What's on the plate? Why, it's <kanji>salt</kanji>!
reading_mnemonic: When you see the <kanji>salt</kanji>, you think to yourself, "<reading>She owe</reading>s (しお) me big time, so I'm going to go ahead and snatch her salt!" Who is she, you ask? She's the lady who owns the salt. And the gun in the dirt, of course.

meaning_mnemonic: In a <radical>yurt</radical> you use a <radical>towel</radical> as a <kanji>seat</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: Something about using a towel for a <kanji>seat</kanji> is very <reading>sexy</reading> (せき) to you. Probably because you associate it with sexy people using towel seats on the beach.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>shellfish</radical> that can't live through <radical>winter</radical> is a <kanji>failure</kanji>. Any proper shellfish would survive through the winter, so this is quite an embarrassing <kanji>defeat</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: The best way to avoid <kanji>failure</kanji> is to say a little <reading>hai</reading>ku (はい) to distract you from the cold. In fact, this can work in any situation where you're afraid of defeat. Say a haiku aloud, it will calm your nerves and warm you from the inside.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>fruit</radical> radical and the <kanji>fruit</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Bodacious!
reading_mnemonic: They sell <kanji>fruit</kanji> at the store, and you need to drive your <reading>ca</reading>r (か) to get there. A car is the fastest way to fruit.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>tree</radical> you aim your <radical>gun</radical> at from your <radical>window</radical> is an <kanji>ume</kanji>, aka a <kanji>Japanese plum</kanji>. Why? Because shooting the ume out of Japanese plum trees is, in your opinion, the best way to harvest plums.
reading_mnemonic: You've probably heard of <kanji>ume</kanji> before, depending on your exposure to Japan, but an <reading>ume</reading> (うめ) is a <kanji>Japanese plum</kanji>.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>nothing</radical> radical and the <kanji>nothing</kanji> kanji are exactly the same! Woah!
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Nothing</kanji> can <reading>moo</reading> (む) quite like a cow can moo. Cows are the best at going moo. That’s a fact.

meaning_mnemonic: You use a <radical>thread</radical> for <radical>good luck</radical> by <kanji>bind</kanji>ing two fingers together. You <kanji>tie</kanji> them nice and tight.
reading_mnemonic: After you <kanji>bind</kanji> your fingers, the good luck starts pouring in. Literally. Suddenly <reading>ketsu</reading>p (けつ) starts pouring down from the heavens.

meaning_mnemonic: Your <radical>mouth</radical> is so <radical>big</radical> that it's the <kanji>cause</kanji> of all your problems.
reading_mnemonic: Your big mouth is the <kanji>cause</kanji> behind all your friends and family moving to an <reading>inn</reading> (いん). They move to the inn so they don't have to live with you and hear you talk anymore.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>viking</radical> with a <radical>mouth</radical> <radical>towel</radical> is a totally <kanji>normal</kanji> thing. It's <kanji>ordinary</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: It's <kanji>normal</kanji> for a viking to have a mouth towel, but your sloppy farmhand friend <reading>Joe</reading>(じょう) has a mouth towel too. That's a habit that's only <kanji>normal</kanji> for vikings, so why does he have one?

meaning_mnemonic: If you can <radical>say</radical> what <radical>sound</radical> a <radical>drunkard</radical> makes, you must be very <kanji>discerning</kanji>. Few people are able to discern what sound a drunkard makes, but you — you can say, because you're a very <kanji>discriminating</kanji> listener.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Discerning</kanji> individuals like you are considered <reading>chic</reading> (しき). What's more chic than your <kanji>discriminating</kanji> way of listening?

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>criminal</radical> has done an <kanji>injustice</kanji> on the world or other people. Being a criminal is a <kanji>negative</kanji> thing, and even if it was just a <kanji>mistake</kanji>, it was still a crime.
reading_mnemonic: When you commit an <kanji>injustice</kanji>, you'll know because <reading>he</reading>at (ひ) fills your body. Maybe you've never done any kind of big thing, but when you make a <kanji>mistake</kanji> your face fills with heat and you turn red!

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>dry</radical> radical and the <kanji>dry</kanji> kanji are the same!
reading_mnemonic: You need to <kanji>dry</kanji> Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん). He hates being wet, all of the Mongols do, so your job is to dry his entire body. And his clothes, and his horse. In fact, when it rains, you have to ride next to him keeping him dry by holding an umbrella above his head.

meaning_mnemonic: The <radical>sun</radical> is <radical>correct</radical>, <kanji>absolutely</kanji>. The mighty sun is never wrong. It is absolutely correct, always.
reading_mnemonic: Then, a <reading>ze</reading>ppelin (ぜ) flies in front of the sun, blocking it out. <kanji>Absolutely</kanji>, the sun cannot ignore this transgression. Therefore, the sun corrects the zeppelin’s evil ways by frying it with sunshine and bringing it to the ground.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tsunami</radical> is coming, and you want to <radical>walk</radical> over it, so you have to <kanji>ford</kanji> it. You don’t walk across a tsunami, you <kanji>wade</kanji> across it.
reading_mnemonic: Your ability to <kanji>ford</kanji> this tsunami impresses everyone who witnesses it, especially the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう). Now that you've taught him a tsunami can be forded, he's going to start sending his troops through them instead of waiting for them to pass.

meaning_mnemonic: Under this <radical>roof</radical> is a <radical>bear</radical> who works for the <kanji>government</kanji>. If you saw a bear out in the wild you might be afraid and try to run, but if you see a bear inside a building under a roof, don't be scared! It's just a government bear.
reading_mnemonic: The first <kanji>government</kanji> that allowed bears was set up by Genghis <reading>Khan</reading> (かん). He was all about conquering people and then using them as efficiently as possible. He discovered that bears are incredibly useful in government buildings as government workers.

meaning_mnemonic: If you're on the <radical>roof</radical> of the <radical>festival</radical> you'll have to <kanji>guess</kanji> what's actually going on below you. You can kind of see that there are rides and maybe food? It smells like food. But you have to guess on the specifics because you're above it and not in it.
reading_mnemonic: To get a better <kanji>guess</kanji>, you ask <reading>Satsu</reading>ki (さつ) for help. She's that little girl you know from some earlier mnemonics, and she happens to be up on the roof with you. Picture her as you ask, "What's your guess, Satsuki?"

meaning_mnemonic: Under a <radical>canopy</radical> your <radical>clan</radical> digs in the <radical>ground</radical>, trying to get to the <kanji>bottom</kanji>. They want to build a nice home your entire clan can live in, but they need to get to the bottom before they'll start building.
reading_mnemonic: Suddenly someone down in the hole shouts that they've reached the <kanji>bottom</kanji>, but it's full of water and they're all <reading>soak</reading>ed (そこ)!

meaning_mnemonic: Put on <radical>cleat</radical>s so you can plant a kiss on your sweetheart's <radical>forehead</radical> in the <radical>heart</radical> of <radical>winter</radical> — that's <kanji>love</kanji>. You'll be braving the harsh winter elements for love, so you put on your cleats to get a better grip on the snow. Sure, you could just wait for better weather to go see them, but then it wouldn't be true love, would it?
reading_mnemonic: Walking through the winter snow with your cleats on, you've gotta keep your <reading>eye</reading> (あい) on the prize. It's a really hard journey, but you keep your eye on the prize, which is your <kanji>love</kanji> and the time you'll get to spend with them.

meaning_mnemonic: This <radical>net</radical> is for <radical>someone</radical> who works in a <kanji>government office</kanji>. You'll also take someone from a <kanji>political office</kanji>.
reading_mnemonic: <kanji>Government office</kanji> and <kanji>political office</kanji> people put on the best <reading>show</reading>s (しょ). That's why you want to capture someone from there with your net.

meaning_mnemonic: You have a <radical>poem</radical> about <radical>winter</radical> that you <radical>say</radical> to <kanji>warn</kanji> people against going outside. It's cold and dangerous in winter! You <kanji>admonish</kanji> anyone and everyone you see going out there with your scary winter poem.
reading_mnemonic: To make sure people listen to your <kanji>warn</kanji>ing, you threaten to take away their <reading>ca</reading>ke (けい). People will do anything for cake, so when you bring it up, they actually take your attempts to warn them about winter seriously.

meaning_mnemonic: <radical>Again</radical> and again, your <radical>heart</radical> comes back to the same person. Is this <kanji>romance</kanji>? Are you in <kanji>love</kanji>?
reading_mnemonic: But, remember that your <kanji>romance</kanji> isn’t a <reading>ren</reading>tal (れん). You really wanna reserve it for the right person!

meaning_mnemonic:
<radical>Viking</radical> <radical>see</radical>, Viking <kanji>memorize</kanji>. That’s how Vikings learn things. They see something, and then they memorize it. Quite simple, really.

It can also mean <kanji>awake</kanji>. Just remember that Vikings can't see if they aren't awake. There won't be anything to memorize if their eyes are still closed, after all!
reading_mnemonic: Every morning, a <reading>cock</reading> (かく) crows and rouses the Vikings. Seeing this, one of the Vikings <kanji>memorize</kanji>s the cock crow so that he can mimic it and play pranks on his fellow Vikings.

meaning_mnemonic: What do you <radical>say</radical> to a <radical>guard</radical>? Your <kanji>theory</kanji> about how the thing he's guarding isn't even real. Yeah, you have this whole thing figured out. You have for a while. At this point, it's only fair that you tell your theory to the guard who's wasting his time.
reading_mnemonic: The guard listens to your <kanji>theory</kanji> but then he says his OWN! He thinks there are two <reading>sets</reading> (せつ) of guarded items, and he's only guarding one. According to his theory, either one could be real! His theory is more plausible, don't you think?

meaning_mnemonic: You hide <radical>poop</radical> in a <radical>cape</radical> as part of the <kanji>illusion</kanji> in your magic show. Your acts are kind of gross and this one involves creating the illusion of disappearing poop by hiding it within the folds of your cape.
reading_mnemonic: Somehow the poop cape <kanji>illusion</kanji> goes over really well. The crowd is giving you a standing ovation and right in the center is <reading>Gen</reading>ji (げん). He marches up to you, wipes a tear from his eye, and says, "Your illusion cape is wonderful. I must have it!"

meaning_mnemonic: They <radical>say</radical> <radical>sheep</radical> are <kanji>detailed</kanji> creatures. I mean, I never thought sheep were very detailed, but that’s what they say.
reading_mnemonic: The reason these sheep are so <kanji>detailed</kanji> is that they are trying to impress the <reading>Shou</reading>gun (しょう). If they're fancy enough, perhaps the Shougun won’t kill them for their meat and make their wool into clothing.

meaning_mnemonic: A <radical>tiger</radical> kills a <radical>pig</radical> with a <radical>knife</radical> in this new <kanji>drama</kanji> about the animal kingdom! The tiger and pig used to be friends when they were younger, but now they're bitter enemies and the tiger just stabbed the pig right in the chest with a knife.
reading_mnemonic: This <kanji>drama</kanji> is being put on by <reading>Gecki</reading> (げき), your childhood pet gecko. Gecki is playing all the parts, because as true drama fans know, one-gecko-shows are the highest form of art.

examples.en: Is rucksack a foreign word?
examples.ja: リュックサックは、外来語ですか？

examples.en: In fact, "ikura" is a loanword from Russia.
examples.ja: 実は、「イクラ」は、ロシアからの外来語なんです。

examples.en: In present day Chinese, many Japanese words are used as loanwords.
examples.ja: 今の中国語では、たくさんの日本語が外来語として使われています。

examples.en: In Japan, we often use foreign words. Foreign words are becoming so much a part of Japanese culture that sometimes Japanese and foreign words are difficult to tell apart.
examples.ja: 日本では外来語を使う事が多いです。たまに日本語と外来語が見分けられないほど、外来語は日本文化の一部になりつつあります。

meaning_mnemonic: You know the word 外来 to mean "imported." So, combine that with the kanji for <kanji>language</kanji> and you have an imported word, aka a <vocabulary>borrowed word</vocabulary>. There are a lot of these in Japanese, which makes this word important. Almost everything in katakana is a 外来語, in fact.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I don't want to see her sad.
examples.ja: 彼女が悲しむのは見たくありません。

examples.en: Animals, as well as humans, are saddened by the deaths of their friends.
examples.ja: 人間だけではなく、動物も仲間の死を悲しみます。

examples.en: She was very saddened by the loss of her beloved pet.
examples.ja: 彼女は愛するペットが亡くなってとても悲しんでいます。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>sad</kanji> and this verb is transitive, so it means <vocabulary>to be sad about</vocabulary> something. Boohoo.
reading_mnemonic: If you're going <vocabulary>to be sad about</vocabulary> something right now, it will be <reading>kana</reading> (かな). Don't use kana when you're trying to learn kanji! You'll be sad forever if you're stuck using kana your whole life, so don't let that habit start now, friend.

examples.en: I am very happy to see my son's happy face.
examples.ja: 息子の喜ぶ顔が見れてとてもうれしいです。

examples.en: If even one person claims to be my fan, I will weep and rejoice!
examples.ja: 私のファンだと言う人が一人でもいたら、泣いて喜びます！

examples.en: I hate myself for not being able to enjoy the success of others.
examples.ja: 他人の成功を喜べない自分がキライです。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>rejoice</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to rejoice</vocabulary>. Though <vocabulary>to become happy</vocabulary> probably sounds a little more natural.
reading_mnemonic: You start <vocabulary>to rejoice</vocabulary> by saying, "<reading>Yo, rock on</reading> (よろこ)!" Now you know how to rejoice from now on. At church or temple? "Yo, rock on!" Perfect.

examples.en: Medications are needed to cure this disease.
examples.ja: この病気を治すには薬が必要です。

examples.en: Do you know how to heal scratches fast?
examples.ja: キズを早く治す方法を知っていますか？

examples.en: To cure a scratchy throat, it's best to tie a leek around your neck.
examples.ja: ノドのイガイガを治すには、ネギを首にくくっておくのが一番です。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. 

The kanji itself means <kanji>cure</kanji>, and this verb means <vocabulary>to cure</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to heal</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to ease</vocabulary> something. This particular verb is when someone does the curing. The illness or injury doesn't just get better by itself. How can you remember that? Because when you try to heal someone and you mess up, they can try to <reading>sue</reading> (す) you.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

I need you <vocabulary>to heal</vocabulary> him, and I need you to heal him right <reading>now</reading> (なお). NOW NOW NOW! 

This also shares the reading for 直す, a very similar word you learned previously, which means "to fix." I'm guessing that the Japanese word なおす was only one word ("to fix" and "to cure" are pretty similar, right?). Then, there were two Chinese words for it (as you can see with the kanji), so the one Japanese word got split into two very similar words.

examples.en: Until what year B.C. was the Tyrannosaurus present?
examples.ja: ティラノサウルスがいたのは、紀元前何年ごろまでですか。

examples.en: If time machines existed, I would want to go to 3000 BCE.
examples.ja: もしタイムマシーンがあったなら、紀元前三千年紀に行ってみたいな。

examples.en: Today, Koichi insists that he is a man who has traveled back in time from ancient Rome, B.C.
examples.ja: 今日のコウイチは、自分は紀元前の古代ローマからタイムスリップしてきた男だって言ってきかないんです。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 紀元後 is "Common Era", or "anno Domini"? Well, this is the opposite because it has <kanji>before</kanji> (前) instead of 後. It's <vocabulary>Before the Common Era</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>Before Christ</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will also help if you know how to read 紀元後 already, because then you'll just have to remember the 前.

examples.en: I made ham and cheese sandwiches for breakfast.
examples.ja: 朝ご飯にはハムとチーズのサンドイッチを作りました。

examples.en: For breakfast at my house, it's always rice instead of bread.
examples.ja: ウチの朝ご飯は、パンじゃなくご飯と決まっています。

examples.en: Having cereal for breakfast every morning isn't very good for your health.
examples.ja: 毎朝シリアルを朝ご飯にするのは、あまり体に良くないです。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>morning</kanji> <kanji>meal</kanji> is the meal you eat in the morning. That is <vocabulary>breakfast</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji. It's also like the vocab: 朝 is like the vocab version, あさ and ご飯 is like the word you learned, ごはん.

examples.en: Hey, crybaby Ko-chan. Here comes a tunnel you like.
examples.ja: 泣き虫コウちゃーん、ほら、コウちゃんの好きなトンネルだよーっ！

examples.en: Only Koichi knows Viet is a crybaby.
examples.ja: コウイチだけがビエトが泣き虫だということを知っている。

examples.en: My kid's high fever doesn't seem to be coming down. She is usually a crybaby, but it seems like she doesn't even have energy to cry now and I'm worried.
examples.ja: ウチの子の高熱が中々下がりません。いつもは泣き虫なんですが、今は泣く元気も無いようで、心配です。

meaning_mnemonic: You've seen that 泣く is to cry, so you can probably guess that 泣き is just "cry." You've also seen how 虫 is rarely a nice thing to call someone. So what's a mean thing you can call someone who cries? How about a <vocabulary>crybaby</vocabulary>?
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from 泣く and 虫. So long as you're okay with those two words you should be able to read this one too.

examples.en: I can hear a baby is crying.
examples.ja: 赤ちゃんの泣き声が聞こえます。

examples.en: Koichi's cry is actually really cute.
examples.ja: コウイチの泣き声って、実はめちゃくちゃカワイイんだよ。

examples.en: If you get irritated by the crying of small children, as an adult, you could just wear headphones with noise cancellation, I think.
examples.ja: 小さい子の泣き声にイライラするなら、大人だったら自分でヘッドフォンしてノイズキャンセルすれば良いのにって思う。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>cry</kanji> <kanji>voice</kanji> is a sound of <vocabulary>crying</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>sob</vocabulary>. Don't cry! Kanji will get easier someday!
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the vocab words 泣く and 声. So long as you know those two words okay, you should be able to read this word too!

examples.en: Would you like to have dinner at our place?
examples.ja: 晩ご飯、良かったらウチで食べていく？

examples.en: Before the dinner, I drank down a glass of beer in one gulp.
examples.ja: 晩ご飯の前に、ビールを一気にグビッと飲み干しました。

examples.en: Tonight's supper is salted, sun-dried flounder.
examples.ja: 今日の晩ご飯のオカズは、天日干しで作ったカレイの干物です。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>night</kanji> <kanji>meal</kanji> is the meal you eat at night. That is <vocabulary>dinner</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I want to eat curry rice for lunch.
examples.ja: 昼ご飯にはカレーライスが食べたいです。

examples.en: Why don't we order pizza for lunch?
examples.ja: 昼ご飯は、ピザを注文しない？

examples.en: There was no time for lunch today.
examples.ja: 今日は昼ご飯を食べる時間はありませんでした。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>noon</kanji> <kanji>meal</kanji> is the meal you eat at noon. What meal is that? It's delicious, delicious <vocabulary>lunch</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from the words 昼 and ご飯. If you know how to read those words you can read this word as well.

examples.en: She made a wish on the first star.
examples.ja: 彼女は、一番星に願い事をしました。

examples.en: The deity of this shrine is famous for listening to wishes.
examples.ja: こちらの神社の神様は、願い事を聞いてくださることで有名です。

examples.en: The man put his hands together in prayer with his wish in mind.
examples.ja: 男は願い事を心に思いながら、手を合わせて祈りました。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that お願い means "a request," and 事 can mean "thing." Well, a request for some specific thing can also be called <vocabulary>one's wish</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>prayer</vocabulary>. Do you have any 願い事 in your heart right now? Of course you do! Don't worry, you can tell me.
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from the words お願い and 事. If you know how to read those you should be able to read this word too. Just remember that 事 is rendaku'd, so it's read as ごと.

examples.en: That comedy duo is from the Kansai region.
examples.ja: あのコンビは関西の芸人です。

examples.en: This guy is a total noob in Kansai, so we’ll have to show him around.
examples.ja: こいつは関西は完全に初心者だから、俺らがガイドしてやらないとな。

examples.en: I heard that people from Kanto and people from Kansai don't get along well. Is it true?
examples.ja: 関東の人と関西の人って折が合わないって聞いたんですが、本当ですか。

meaning_mnemonic:
Get <kanji>connected</kanji> to <kanji>west</kanji> Japan by going to <vocabulary>Kansai</vocabulary>! 

関西 is a region in western Japan that includes cities like Osaka, Kyoto, and Kobe. To get to West Japan, you have to pass through (or over) it, so you can think of it as the geographical beginning of western Japan.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses on'yomi readings. The 西 on'yomi is usually going to be せい, which you've seen before, but in this word it's さい. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember that:

Ugh, tricky readings like the one for <vocabulary>Kansai</vocabulary> really make you want to <reading>sigh</reading> (さい).

examples.en: The steering wheels of Japanese cars are usually on the right side.
examples.ja: 日本の自動車のハンドルは通常右側にあります。

examples.en: My right eye is blurry.
examples.ja: 右側の目がボヤけるんです。

examples.en: There's a lot of salt in the right-hand drawer of Koichi's desk.
examples.ja: コウイチのデスクの右側の引き出しには、塩がたくさん入っています。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>right</kanji> <kanji>side</kanji> is the <vocabulary>right side</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is all kun'yomi vocab reading. You should know the reading of the vocab word 右 by now. Also, the 側 reading happens to be the reading you learned with the kanji as well as with the word 側.

examples.en: Everybody stands on the left side on this escalator I guess.
examples.ja: このエスカレーターでは、みんな左側に立っていますね。

examples.en: They drive on the left in Japan the same as they do in England.
examples.ja: 日本は、イギリスと同じで、車は左側通行ですよ。

examples.en: I prefer to lie with my left side down.
examples.ja: 私は左側を下にして横になる方が好きです。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>left</kanji> <kanji>side</kanji> is the <vocabulary>left side</vocabulary>. Simple as that.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this is vocab kun'yomi readings. Just take the vocab 左 and add it to 側 to have yourself <reading>ひだりがわ</reading>.

examples.en: To keep the zombies out, we lowered the shutters and locked them out from the inside.
examples.ja: ゾンビを中に入れないために、シャッターを下ろして、内側からカギをかけました。

examples.en: I think I got a splinter in the inside of my right thigh.
examples.ja: 右の太ももの内側にトゲがささったみたいです。

examples.en: She oozes beauty from within.
examples.ja: 彼女は、美しさが内側からにじみ出ている。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>inside</kanji> <kanji>side</kanji> is the <vocabulary>inside</vocabulary>. A little redundant but makes a lot of sense.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi readings. With 側 you've already learned it. With 内 you've also already learned the reading. Combine them together and you have うちがわ. In case you've forgotten, here's a mnemonic to help you remember that pesky うち portion. What is it that's drawn you inside? "<reading>Oo, chee</reading>se!" (うち) Cheese has drawn you inside. You're so excited that you exclaim, "Oo, cheese!"

examples.en: I thought this door opened outward, but it actually opens inward, I guess.
examples.ja: 外側に開くと思ったら、内側に開くドアだったんだね。

examples.en: I usually put the key in the outside pocket though....weird.
examples.ja: いつもは外側のポケットにカギを入れておくんですけど...おかしいなぁ。

examples.en: With this takoyaki maker, you can make the outside crispy even on a gas stove!
examples.ja: このタコ焼き器を使えば、ガスコンロでも外側がカリカリにできますよ！

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>outside</kanji> <kanji>side</kanji> is the <vocabulary>outside</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings from the kanji. Since you learned the kun'yomi reading for 外 with the vocabulary, you should be just fine here.

examples.en: Both of my ears itch immensely.
examples.ja: 両側の耳がかゆくてムズムズします。

examples.en: Escalators are actually safer if you stand still without walking and stand on both sides.
examples.ja: エスカレーターは本当は安全上、歩かずに止まって両側に立つものなんだよね。

examples.en: A picture of Viet, with girls on both sides of him, was sold to the paparazzi.
examples.ja: 両側に女の子をはべらせたビエトの写真がパパラッチに売りつけられた。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Both</kanji> <kanji>side</kanji>s is <vocabulary>both sides</vocabulary>. Which side? Both sides.

両側 typically refers to both sides in a physical sense, like saying there are houses on both sides of the street or handrails on both sides of a staircase.
reading_mnemonic: The first kanji takes the on'yomi reading and the second takes the kun'yomi reading. Luckily you know both of them already!

examples.en: Mt. Fuji can be seen to the east.
examples.ja: 東側にはふじ山が見えます。

examples.en: The balcony is on the east side of the apartment.
examples.ja: バルコニーはアパートの東側にあります。

examples.en: You can see the sunrise from the windows on the east side.
examples.ja: 東側のマドからは、日の出が見られます。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>east</kanji> <kanji>side</kanji> is the <vocabulary>east side</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the kun'yomi readings you first learned with each kanji. As long as you remember this is double kun'yomi, you're good to go.

examples.en: There are hardly any military personnel left in that country anymore.
examples.ja: もうあの国には、兵員はほとんど残っていません。

examples.en: Everyone everywhere is short of troops. It is not just a problem for our country.
examples.ja: どこもみんな、兵員不足は変わりませんよ。ウチの国だけの問題ではありません。

examples.en: How are you going to recruit soldiers when the people don't believe in us?
examples.ja: 国民たちが私たちのことを信じていない中で、どうやって兵員を集めるつもりなんですか？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>soldier</kanji> <kanji>member</kanji> (or a member of the soldiers) is a person that is of the <vocabulary>military personnel</vocabulary>. It also shows the amount of <vocabulary>military strength</vocabulary> an army has. The more soldier members, the more military strength and military personnel it has!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This is my ultimate weapon!
examples.ja: これが俺の最終兵器だ！

examples.en: I used to work at a chemical weapons laboratory.
examples.ja: 化学兵器の研究室で働いていたことがあります。

examples.en: We discussed whether using arms was right or wrong.
examples.ja: 私たちは兵器使用の是非について語り合いました。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>container</kanji>s that <kanji>soldier</kanji>s use aren't just bowls and stuff, they're the things that hold their <vocabulary>arms</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>weapons</vocabulary>. Think spear and sword containers, full of weapons!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: He is a former soldier.
examples.ja: 彼は元兵士です。

examples.en: Of the 300, only 14 soldiers remain.
examples.ja: 300人のうち、残った兵士はわずか14人です。

examples.en: The soldier's eyes silently informed me of this.
examples.ja: 兵士の目は無言で私にそのことを伝えた。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>soldier</kanji> <kanji>samurai</kanji> is still just another <vocabulary>soldier</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Why is that US soldier wearing pince-nez glasses?
examples.ja: あの米兵は、どうして鼻メガネをかけているの？

examples.en: There are many U.S. soldiers passing through here, so please don't be a distraction to the traffic.
examples.ja: ここは米兵がたくさん通るので、通行のジャマにならないようにしてください。

examples.en: The American soldier is looking for land to build a new house.
examples.ja: その米兵は新しい家を建てるために土地を探しています。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 米国 is "America." Well, more of that again. With 米 representing "America" you can combine that with 兵 (<kanji>soldier</kanji>) to have yourself a <vocabulary>US soldier</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>American soldier</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: What is the cause of the fight?
examples.ja: ケンカの原因は何ですか？

examples.en: Due to the wildfire of unknown origins, the town has been in such a chaotic situation.
examples.ja: 原因不明の山火事で、町は大変なことになっています。

examples.en: The cause of his illness is said to be work-related stress.
examples.ja: 彼の病気の原因は仕事でのストレスだと言われています。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>original</kanji> <kanji>cause</kanji> is how you got into this mess. Forget all the things it caused, the first <vocabulary>cause</vocabulary> is the <vocabulary>origin</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>source</vocabulary> of what's going on right now. You can pinpoint one thing that caused all of this!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I would like to study atomic energy in college.
examples.ja: 大学で、原子エネルギーの勉強をしたいと思っています。

examples.en: What was the atomic number and atomic symbol of this atom?
examples.ja: この原子の原子番号と原子記号は何だったっけ？

examples.en: Everything is made of atoms and molecules.
examples.ja: 全ての物は原子や分子でできています。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>original</kanji> <kanji>child</kanji> of everything is the <vocabulary>atom</vocabulary>. It is the child from which everything else is created, for it was the original child. Atoms are the building blocks of all things!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Comic book movies often lose the flavor of the original work.
examples.ja: マンガが原作の映画は、原作の良さを失ってしまうことが多いです。

examples.en: Have you read Shakespeare's original works?
examples.ja: シェイクスピアを原作で読んだことはありますか？

examples.en: I got an autograph from the original author.
examples.ja: 原作者の方にサインをもらいました。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>original</kanji> thing you <kanji>make</kanji> is the <vocabulary>original work</vocabulary>. It's always better to have the original, rather than a copy, I think.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: What do you think the main cause of inflation is?
examples.ja: インフレの主因って何だと思いますか？

examples.en: The main culprit is ultra-processed food.
examples.ja: 主因はウルトラプロセスフードですよ。

examples.en: The main cause behind the near-miss was that the train sped up when it wasn't supposed to.
examples.ja: ニアミスの主因は、この電車がスピードを上げるべきではないタイミングで上げたことです。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>main</kanji> <kanji>cause</kanji> is the <vocabulary>main cause</vocabulary> or the <vocabulary>primary cause</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Do you want to eat lunch in the cafeteria?
examples.ja: お昼ごはん、食堂で食べない？

examples.en: There are several eateries near my house.
examples.ja: 私の家の近くには、食堂がいくつかあります。

examples.en: When I went to the Tofugu dining hall a while ago, there was free live music from some singer I didn't know.
examples.ja: さっきトーフグ食堂に行ったんだけど、無名の歌手が無料のワンマンライブをしてたよ。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>eat</kanji>ing <kanji>hall</kanji> is a big room in which you eat. What big rooms do you eat in? How about a <vocabulary>cafeteria</vocabulary>, a <vocabulary>dining hall</vocabulary>, or a <vocabulary>diner</vocabulary>?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: It might be better with a little more salt.
examples.ja: もう少し塩が多い方が良いかもしれませんね。

examples.en: I love salt ramen.
examples.ja: 私は塩ラーメンが大好きです。

examples.en: Until your baby turns one year old, you shouldn't give them any salt.
examples.ja: 一才になるまで赤ちゃんには塩をあげない方がいいですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, no extra salt needed.

examples.en: I drink salt water every day.
examples.ja: 私は毎日塩水を飲んでいます。

examples.en: Let broccoli soak in salted water for five minutes.
examples.ja: ブロッコリーは、塩水に5分つけておきます。

examples.en: Sea water stings on wounds because it's salty.
examples.ja: 海水は塩水なのでキズにしみます。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Water</kanji> with <kanji>salt</kanji> in it is <vocabulary>salt water</vocabulary>. Best not to drink 塩水.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. You know 塩's from the kanji and you know 水's from the vocab word 水. Combine them together and you have <reading>しおみず</reading>.

examples.en: I think it lacks a little saltiness.
examples.ja: 塩味が少し足りない気がします。

examples.en: Lightly-salted potato chips aren't that popular.
examples.ja: うす塩味のポテトチップスは、あまり人気がありません。

examples.en: Salty olives are an essential ingredient in Greek salad.
examples.ja: グリークサラダには、塩味の利いたオリーブが欠かせません。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>taste</kanji> of <kanji>salt</kanji> is a <vocabulary>salty taste</vocabulary> (it's also when something <vocabulary>tastes salty</vocabulary>).
reading_mnemonic:
The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. So, take the readings of 塩 (you learned the reading with the kanji) and 味 and you have yourself <reading>しおあじ</reading>.

If you happen to be a cooking show fan, you might also hear the on'yomi reading of this word - <reading>えんみ</reading>. This word can also be read as <reading>しおみ</reading>, which has more or less the same meaning as the primary reading you learned.

examples.en: No matter what happens, never misuse government money!
examples.ja: ゼッタイに官金に手を出すんじゃないぞ！

examples.en: That politician was blinded by government money.
examples.ja: あの政治家は官金に目がくらんだんだよ。

examples.en: Do you think that taking a child to daycare in a government car is, in a sense, a misuse of government funds?
examples.ja: 保育園まで公用車に子どもを乗せて行くことは、ある意味で官金の私消に当たると思いますか？

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Government</kanji> <kanji>gold</kanji> (aka money) is what makes up <vocabulary>government funds</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: He is a former diplomat.
examples.ja: 彼は元外交官です。

examples.en: My father is a diplomat and a diplomat from another country gave him a rare guitar, which is one of only a few that exist in the world.
examples.ja: 私の父は外交官で、世界に数台しかないギターを他の国の外交官からプレゼントされました。

examples.en: The diplomat does not seem to know much about fashion.
examples.ja: その外交官はファッションについては詳しくないようです。

meaning_mnemonic: Someone from the <kanji>outside</kanji> who comes in to <kanji>mix</kanji> with the <kanji>government</kanji> is a <vocabulary>diplomat</vocabulary>. Really, that's what diplomats do, right? They come from the outside (country). They mix with the government, and they do what they're there to do!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: You should take care of your own feelings before you take care of other people's feelings.
examples.ja: 人の気持ちを察する前に、自分の気持ちを大切にするべきです。

examples.en: Even without telling them, I wanted them at least to guess that it wasn’t the only reason.
examples.ja: 言わなくても、それだけが理由じゃないことくらい察してもらいたかった。

examples.en: When I was in elementary school, I told my name to the mother of the first friend I ever made, and her expression changed. After that, the child suddenly stopped hanging out with me. I was eight at the time, but I understood everything.
examples.ja: 小学生の時、初めて仲良くなった子の母親に名前を言うと、顔色が変わった。それ以後、その子は急に私とつるまなくなった。当時八才だったが、全て察した。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>guess</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to guess</vocabulary>. Alternatively, you can learn this as <vocabulary>to sense</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to presume</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this is actually the same as what you learned with the kanji, but the さつ is shortened to さっ. If you had <vocabulary>to guess</vocabulary> be sure to guess with the shorter つ.

examples.en: She is very good at sensing danger.
examples.ja: 彼女は危険察知能力が高い。

examples.en: He sensed his boss's frustration and stayed as far away from him as possible.
examples.ja: 彼は上司のイライラを察知し、出来るだけ近づかないようにしました。

examples.en: Viet and his foot soldiers seemed to have sensed that the police would raid them.
examples.ja: ビエトと手下たちは、警察の手入れがあることを事前に察知していたようだ。

meaning_mnemonic: Okay, so you <kanji>guess</kanji> but you also kind of <kanji>know</kanji>. You can make an <vocabulary>inference</vocabulary> as to what the answer is... You're not 100% sure, but you think you know, even though you're guessing.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You know the 察 part, although it gets shortened to さっ here. You didn't learn 知's on'yomi when you learned the kanji, though, so here's a mnemonic to help you with it:

One <vocabulary>inference</vocabulary> everyone can make is that you probably want to eat some <reading>chee</reading>se (ち). Seriously, it's written all over your face. You can try to hide it, but everyone saw how hot and bothered you just got in the dairy section. It doesn't take a mind-reader to <vocabulary>sense</vocabulary> how bad you're jonesing for some cheese.

examples.en: I'm afraid that we request that seated customers please order something from the menu.
examples.ja: おそれ入りますが、お席をご利用されるさいは、メニューから何か一つご注文をお願いします。

examples.en: Let's put everybody's bags on the seat to the right of me.
examples.ja: 私の右側の席にみんなの荷物をおきましょう。

examples.en: "Excuse me. Could you move over and let me sit down, please?" "I’m sorry, this seat is taken."
examples.ja: 「すみませんが、席を詰めて私を座らせてもらえませんか？」「申し訳ないんですが、この席は空いてないんです。」

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the on you learned with the kanji. Have a seat and relax.

examples.en: I will be absent tomorrow.
examples.ja: 明日は欠席します。

examples.en: There were zero absences from yesterday's meeting.
examples.ja: 昨日のミーティングの欠席者はゼロでした。

examples.en: I had to miss the graduation ceremony because I got COVID.
examples.ja: コロナにかかってしまったので、卒業式は欠席しなくちゃいけませんでした。

meaning_mnemonic: When a <kanji>seat</kanji> is <kanji>lack</kanji>ing the person it's supposed to have in it, there is an <vocabulary>absence</vocabulary>. Where is Johnny? Another absence? Ugh. Johnny. C'mon.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note that the けつ is shortened to けっ as つs often are when in a situation like this.

examples.en: I'm afraid that my attendance will probably be irregular.
examples.ja: すみませんが、出席は不定期になると思います。

examples.en: I'm not planning to attend Koichi's birthday party.
examples.ja: コウイチのバースデーパーティーには、出席しない予定です。

examples.en: Could you put me on another flight? I really have to attend the G7.
examples.ja: 別の便に乗せていただけますか？どうしても、G7に出席しなくてはならないんです。

meaning_mnemonic: The people who <kanji>exit</kanji> their <kanji>seat</kanji>s at the end of the show are the number of people who showed up, not counting empty seats. This is the true <vocabulary>attendance</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note the しゅつ gets changed to しゅっ, as many つs do in this situation.

examples.en: No seats are available on this flight.
examples.ja: このフライトに空席はありません。

examples.en: Are there still many open seats left? If possible, I’d prefer to sit in the front.
examples.ja: まだ空席はたくさんありますか？できれば前の方の席がいいのですが。

examples.en: I went to see a movie on Christmas day in the U.S. and I was surprised to see that the theater was nearly empty.
examples.ja: アメリカでクリスマスに映画を見に行ったら、ほとんど空席でびっくりしました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>sky</kanji> <kanji>seat</kanji> is a seat full of sky (aka nothing!). This is an <vocabulary>empty seat</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>open seat</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: He is always smiling.
examples.ja: 彼は常に笑顔です。

examples.en: My mother is always running.
examples.ja: 私の母は常に走っています。

examples.en: It takes some kids a while to realize their parents aren’t always right.
examples.ja: 自分の親が常に正しいわけではないことを知るのに、時間がかかる子どももいます。

meaning_mnemonic: The particle に here is a clue that this word is an adverb. An adverb describes actions, so what's a <kanji>normal</kanji> action? It's one you're <vocabulary>always</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>constantly</vocabulary>, doing. That's what makes it normal!
reading_mnemonic:
The reading is the kun'yomi reading, which you didn't learn. In order to learn it, think of this:

I <vocabulary>always</vocabulary> <reading>tune</reading> (つね) my violin, but today I didn't tune it. So, now I sound terrible. Imagine how terrible my untuned violin sounds, compared to how it always sounds.

examples.en: I want to be able to have daily conversations in Japanese.
examples.ja: 私は日本語で日常会話が出来るようになりたいです。

examples.en: I do my daily shopping on Amazon.
examples.ja: 日常の買い物はアマゾンですませます。

examples.en: I would like to know what the daily life of Koichi is like.
examples.ja: コウイチの日常がどんなものなのか知りたいです。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Normal</kanji> <kanji>day</kanji>s are what you have in your regular <vocabulary>everyday life</vocabulary>. This is your <vocabulary>normal life</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I was relieved that you guys have common sense.
examples.ja: 常識のある人たちばかりで、安心しました。

examples.en: Dealing with people who lack common sense is stressful.
examples.ja: 常識がない人との付き合いはストレスです。

examples.en: Common sense suggests that the plan won't succeed.
examples.ja: 常識的に考えれば、その計画は成功しないだろう。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Normal</kanji> <kanji>discerning</kanji> is the discerning you do on a daily basis, without thinking. It is all the things that you do that are <vocabulary>common sense</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Oh, do you hang your underwear outside to dry?
examples.ja: え、下着を外に干すの？

examples.en: If you're looking for bath towels, they're hanging there, right?
examples.ja: バスタオルなら、そこに干してあるでしょ？

examples.en: I think that comedian has definitely been deprived of any chance to appear on television recently. Don't you agree?
examples.ja: あの芸人、ゼッタイ最近干されてるよね。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>dry</kanji> and the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to dry something</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Why do you need <vocabulary>to dry something</vocabulary>? Because someone used a <reading>hose</reading> (ほす) and got everything all wet. Ugh, you shouldn't leave that hose out anymore...

examples.en: It's said that the pond at this shrine had water no matter what kind of dry weather there was.
examples.ja: この神社の池には、どんな干天でもゼッタイに水があったんだって。

examples.en: Here, it suddenly started pouring rain last night, completely different from the dry weather we've had until now.
examples.ja: こちらでは、今までの干天がウソのように、昨夜から急に大雨になっています。

examples.en: Maybe it's because we've had a drought all these years, but the river is not flowing.
examples.ja: ここ最近ずっと干天だったせいか、川の水が流れてないんですよね。

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 天気 is weather (and how 天 often refers to sky things?). Well, when those sky things are dry, you have <vocabulary>dry weather</vocabulary>.

Note that 干天 is quite old-fashioned and you'll find it mainly in formal writing and advanced set expressions.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: She likes to interfere in other people's problems.
examples.ja: 彼女は他人の問題に干渉するのが好きだ。

examples.en: If parents interfere too much in school life, the child may feel stressed.
examples.ja: 親が学校生活に干渉しすぎると、子はストレスを感じることがあります。

examples.en: Koichi warned the workers not to interfere in his private life.
examples.ja: コウイチは、私生活への干渉はしないよう社員たちに注意しました。

meaning_mnemonic: When you're <kanji>ford</kanji>ing a stream, and you suddenly feel <kanji>dry</kanji> feelings around you, that doesn't make any sense for something wet. This dryness is an <vocabulary>interference</vocabulary>. It's an <vocabulary>intervention</vocabulary> trying to stop you from fording.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: You'll be able to see apparitions if you take this drug.
examples.ja: この薬を飲むと、幻が見えますよ。

examples.en: I caught a phantom fish!
examples.ja: 幻の魚をつかまえたぞ！

examples.en: It was like a phantom.
examples.ja: それはまるで幻のようだった。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. You can add <vocabulary>phantom</vocabulary> to the meanings as well, because phantoms are kind of like <vocabulary>illusion</vocabulary>s.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You look up to see a crazy <vocabulary>illusion</vocabulary>. You can't believe it's real. Master Roshi, from Dragonball, is standing in front of you (you thought he was a cartoon!). Then, he splits into a million versions of himself, creating a <reading>mob of Roshi</reading>s (まぼろし). This mob goes on to train many people to fight.

examples.en: Isn't that just a hallucination?
examples.ja: それ、ただの幻覚じゃない？

examples.en: I heard that she sometimes has hallucinations when she is recording her podcasts.
examples.ja: 彼女は時々、ポッドキャストをレコーディングしている時に幻覚が見えるそうです。

examples.en: I've heard that hallucinogenic mushrooms grow in that forest.
examples.ja: あの森には幻覚を引き起こすキノコが生えていると聞いたことがあります。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>illusion</kanji> you have when you're <kanji>awake</kanji> is a <vocabulary>hallucination</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: That is an illusion.
examples.ja: それは幻想です。

examples.en: Kyoto nights in autumn are very magical.
examples.ja: 秋の京都の夜って、とても幻想的なんですよ。

examples.en: The atmosphere of the venue was so beautiful that I felt like I was in a fantasy world.
examples.ja: 会場の雰囲気がステキすぎて、まるで幻想の世界にいるような気分になりました。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>illusion</kanji> that you <kanji>imagine</kanji> is your big <vocabulary>fantasy</vocabulary> (it's also an <vocabulary>illusion</vocabulary>). This makes sense, though, right? An illusion is an illusion, sure. But, when you imagine it, it becomes your fantasy!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: There’s gum stuck to the bottom of your shoe.
examples.ja: クツの底にガムがついてるよ。

examples.en: This place is so deep that you can't see the bottom.
examples.ja: ここは底が見えないほど深い。

examples.en: There's still a little medicine left at the bottom.
examples.ja: 底にまだ少し薬が残ってるよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: This vocab uses the same reading as the one you learned with the kanji. Well played!

examples.en: I'm sincerely happy that Koichi's incurable disease actually has been cured.
examples.ja: コウイチの不治の病が治って、心底うれしいよ。

examples.en: I found his statement to be sincerely sickening.
examples.ja: 彼の発言を聞いて、心底気持ち悪いと思いました。

examples.en: I felt really relieved that everyone on the new team are such nice people.
examples.ja: 新しいチーム、みんな良い人ばかりで、心底ホッとしたよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>heart</kanji> <kanji>bottom</kanji> is the <vocabulary>bottom of one's heart</vocabulary>. Do you want to learn kanji? Do you want to learn it from 心底? Okay, fine, you can move onto the reading then.
reading_mnemonic: This word uses the on'yomi reading for the first kanji and the kun'yomi reading for the second kanji. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this too!

examples.en: There were many aquatic plants growing on the river bottom.
examples.ja: 川底には水草がたくさん生えていました。

examples.en: This river is so clean that you can see the river bottom.
examples.ja: この川は川底が見えるほどキレイな川です。

examples.en: He's like a big stone sitting still at the bottom of a river.
examples.ja: 彼は、川底でジッとしている大きな石のような男です。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>river</kanji> <kanji>bottom</kanji> is the <vocabulary>river bottom</vocabulary>, also known as the <vocabulary>riverbed</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji. Just don't forget the rendaku for 底!

examples.en: I haven't truly fallen in love yet.
examples.ja: 私はまだ、恋をしたことがない。

examples.en: He took one look at her and fell in love.
examples.ja: 彼は彼女を一目見て、恋に落ちました。

examples.en: I keep thinking about the carp in the pond at that shrine. Is this the beginning of love?
examples.ja: あの神社の池のコイのこと、ずっと考えちゃうの。これって恋の始まりなのかな？

meaning_mnemonic: When you have <kanji>romance</kanji> you also have <vocabulary>love</vocabulary>! The romantic kind of mushy, gushy love. Be careful though. This word doesn't share its meaning with its kanji. But, that's how romance is. It gets all crazy and turns to love really fast.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: Your <vocabulary>love</vocabulary> isn't toward a person, it's toward this giant <reading>Koi</reading> (こい) fish you met the other day. The fish is just so... so... handsome! You get hearts popping above your head every time you think about this koi!

examples.en: This is a song about lost love.
examples.ja: これは失恋を歌った曲です。

examples.en: I was heartbroken and couldn't get any food down my throat.
examples.ja: 失恋して、食事がノドを通らなくなった。

examples.en: Heartbreak is an everyday occurrence for me.
examples.ja: 失恋なんて、日常茶飯事だよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>fault</kanji> of <kanji>romance</kanji> isn't the romance itself, it's when everything falls apart. It's when you experience <vocabulary>heartbreak</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>unrequited love</vocabulary>. Have you ever felt the fault of romance? If so, remember back to that time, and think about how terrible of a fault it is.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: She does not yet know true love.
examples.ja: 彼女はまだ本当の愛を知りません。

examples.en: If it's going to be this painful, I wish I never knew what love was!
examples.ja: こんなに切ないなら、愛なんて知りたくなかった！

examples.en: I believe that money is more important than love. People often say, "Love can move mountains," but without money, you can't do such things, right?
examples.ja: 私はお金は愛より大切だと思います。よく「愛があれば山でも動かせる」なんて言いますが、お金が無いとそんなことできないでしょ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji. Now that is true kanji <vocabulary>love</vocabulary>.

examples.en: It is better to have patriotism, than not to have it, right?
examples.ja: 愛国心は無いよりある方がいいでしょう。

examples.en: Since you live in Japan, it is natural to have patriotism toward Japan.
examples.ja: 日本に住んでるんだから、日本への愛国心を持つことは自然なことです。

examples.en: A very patriotic man joined Tofugu.
examples.ja: 愛国心がやたらに強い男が、トーフグに入社しました。

meaning_mnemonic: When you have <kanji>love</kanji> for your <kanji>country</kanji> deep within your <kanji>heart</kanji>, that is <vocabulary>patriotism</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I'm having a hard time finding love.
examples.ja: 恋愛がなかなか上手くいかないんだよね。

examples.en: I want to fall in love too, but I don't know how.
examples.ja: 僕だって恋愛したいけど、やり方が分からないんです。

examples.en: My kid has been reading romance novels all the time lately.
examples.ja: うちの子は、最近恋愛小説ばかり読んでいます。

meaning_mnemonic: When you have <kanji>romance</kanji> and <kanji>love</kanji> all in the same package. Well, that is <vocabulary>love</vocabulary>! Ah, love! This is the word used when talking about love, though. You don't use this to say "I love you."
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Please take care of yourself.
examples.ja: お体ご自愛ください。

examples.en: I've decided all by myself that today is self love day, so I'm gonna spoil myself all day long.
examples.ja: 今日は自愛デーにすることに自分で決めたので、一日中自愛しまくっちゃいます。

examples.en: Please take care of yourself as the weather is getting colder.
examples.ja: 寒くなってきておりますので、くれぐれもご自愛くださいませ。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>love</kanji> your <kanji>self</kanji> that is <vocabulary>self love</vocabulary>. You’ll mostly see this word as part of the set phrase ご自愛下さい, which is used in emails and the like to remind the recipients to be good to themselves. Other variations include ご自愛くださいませ, ご自愛を, and ご自愛のほどを.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji, you self lover you.

examples.en: I'm studying sexual love at university.
examples.ja: 大学で、性愛学について勉強しています。

examples.en: Interfering with another married couple's sexual love is just indecent.
examples.ja: 他人の夫婦の性愛に口出しするなんて、下品にもほどがあるよ。

examples.en: I’m not sure if I’m asexual or have erotophobia.
examples.ja: 性欲が無いのか性愛恐怖症なのか自分では判断できません。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Gender</kanji> <kanji>love</kanji> is that kind of love that has to do with gender parts. That's <vocabulary>sexual love</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Have you ever visited Aichi Prefecture?
examples.ja: 愛知県に行ったことがありますか？

examples.en: Wasn't that the store in Aichi Prefecture?
examples.ja: そこって愛知県のお店じゃなかったっけ？

examples.en: There is a beautiful ume grove in Aichi Prefecture.
examples.ja: 愛知県には、美しい梅林があります。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>Love</kanji> <kanji>Know</kanji> <kanji>Prefecture</kanji>! I want to live here, because people must know love! Of course, we don't call it that in English. You'll have to know the reading of the kanji to know the reading of this prefecture, which is <vocabulary>Aichi Prefecture</vocabulary> (jump to the reading to figure this out).
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You didn't learn 知's on'yomi when you learned the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

You know what they really love to know about in <vocabulary>Aichi Prefecture</vocabulary>? <reading>Chee</reading>se (ち). Those folks in Aichi, they're some real cheese know-it-alls. Don't ever bring one to a wine and cheese party, because, man — they will be rattling off cheese facts to you all evening.

examples.en: I never thought that team would lose to a weak team like us.
examples.ja: まさかあのチームがウチみたいな弱小チームに敗れるとは思ってもみなかったよ。

examples.en: The Blue Jays lost the game to the Red Socks with a score of 1 to 3.
examples.ja: ブルージェイズは、レッドソックスに三対一で敗れました。

examples.en: No one wants to lose, but one day there will be a result. Until then, we have to fight with the thought, "We can't lose! We have to fight on until then.”
examples.ja: 誰だって敗れたくはないけど、いつか結果は出るものさ。だからそれまで、「敗れてなるものか！」と思って戦うしかないんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>defeat</kanji>, so this means <vocabulary>to be defeated</vocabulary>, but also <vocabulary>to be unsuccessful</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have been defeated. You lay there on the ground, and the fans around the stadium are disgusted with your performance. Some hipster walks up to you and says: "<reading>Yah, Boo</reading>" (やぶ) referring to how poorly you did. "No boo!", you reply back. "Yah boo", they say again.

examples.en: It is okay to fail. Because learning from your mistakes is what is important.
examples.ja: 失敗しても良いんです。失敗から学ぶことこそが重要なんですから。

examples.en: I never thought that he would fail in that presentation.
examples.ja: あの彼がプレゼンで失敗するとは思ってもみませんでした。

examples.en: To be honest, this movie you made is a flop. However, you can’t let it get you down just because you failed once. Someone said that success is the ability to go from one failure to another with no loss of enthusiasm, right?
examples.ja: 正直言って、君が作ったこの映画は失敗作だね。でも、一度失敗したからといって、クヨクヨしてちゃダメだよ。誰かも、「成功とは、失敗から失敗へと熱意を失うことなく進んでいける能力である」って言ってただろ？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>fault</kanji> and a <kanji>failure</kanji>, all in one. This must have been one big <vocabulary>failure</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>mistake</vocabulary> you've made.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The 失 gets shortened, and 敗 gets rendaku'd, though. Don't make that 失敗.

examples.en: The game's outcome was decided yesterday morning.
examples.ja: その戦いの勝敗なら、昨日の朝決まりましたよ。

examples.en: That one word Koichi said made the difference between victory and defeat.
examples.ja: コウイチのその一言が、勝敗の分かれ目になったんです。

examples.en: My parents always say that it is the process that matters and that winning or losing does not matter, but I believe that winning or losing is what matters.
examples.ja: 私の両親はいつも、大事なのはプロセスで勝敗は問題ではないと言いますが、私は勝敗こそが重要だと思っています。

meaning_mnemonic: You have <kanji>win</kanji> and you have <kanji>defeat</kanji>. When you are talking about both in one word, you have <vocabulary>victory or defeat</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I do not want to be a loser.
examples.ja: 私は敗者にはなりたくありません。

examples.en: There are no words from the winners to the losers.
examples.ja: 勝者から敗者にかける言葉はないんですよ。

examples.en: That dentist was born to be a loser.
examples.ja: その歯医者は、生まれながらの敗者であった。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>defeat</kanji>ed <kanji>someone</kanji> is the <vocabulary>loser</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>the defeated</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Absolutely, please come back to Japan.
examples.ja: また是非日本に来てくださいね。

examples.en: I'd absolutely like to attend Tofugu's party.
examples.ja: トーフグのパーティーには是非出席させていただきたいと思っています。

examples.en: Please let me hear your opinion by all means.
examples.ja: 是非ともあなたの意見を聞かせてください。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Absolutely</kanji> an <kanji>injustice</kanji>! We must <vocabulary>absolutely</vocabulary> punish the perpetrator, <vocabulary>by all means</vocabulary>. First, though, we should probably define <vocabulary>right and wrong</vocabulary>.

This word means "absolutely" when it's used as an adverb, and that's the use you'll hear most in conversation. However, as a noun it means "right and wrong", as in whether something is right or wrong, or good or bad.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Tomatoes are fruits.
examples.ja: トマトは果物です。

examples.en: I always eat fruit for breakfast.
examples.ja: 私は朝食にいつも果物を食べます。

examples.en: Out of all fruit, I like figs the best.
examples.ja: 果物の中では、無花果が一番好きです。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>fruit</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji> is just <vocabulary>fruit</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this is an exception, at least for the 果 portion. To remember this part, imagine yourself asking for some <vocabulary>fruit</vocabulary>. <reading>Could I</reading> (くだ) have some fruit, please?

examples.en: I am anxious to see the results of today's test.
examples.ja: 今日のテストの結果が気になります。

examples.en: What was the result of yesterday's match?
examples.ja: 昨日の試合の結果はどうでしたか？

examples.en: President Koichi often says that results are the most important thing.
examples.ja: コウイチ社長は、結果が一番大事だとよく口にしています。

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>tie</kanji> up all the <kanji>fruit</kanji> because you're going to use them to make giant fruit letters. These giant fruit letters will show the <vocabulary>result</vocabulary> of the big monkey election.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just note that the 結 gets shortened to けっ.

examples.en: I love Japanese plum blossoms.
examples.ja: 私は梅の花が大好きです。

examples.en: Every year around this time, I make plum jam from the plums harvested from our garden.
examples.ja: この時期には、毎年庭で取れた梅で、梅ジャムを作るんです。

examples.en: "Where did you get this many ume?" "I visited an ume orchard today."
examples.ja: 「こんなにたくさんの梅の実、どうしたの？」「今日、梅園に行ってきたんだよ。」

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. It's also the same as the meaning of the kanji / vocab, though you can think of this as <vocabulary> Japanese plum</vocabulary> as well if you want.

examples.en: It's delicious, like plum wine!
examples.ja: 梅酒みたいでおいしい！

examples.en: Is that okay to drink plum wine on the trains in Japan?
examples.ja: 日本では、電車の中で梅酒を飲んでもいいんですか？

examples.en: He always orders plum wine on the rocks after beer.
examples.ja: 彼はいつもビールの後に、梅酒ロックを注文します。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Alcohol</kanji> that comes from <kanji>ume</kanji> is <vocabulary>ume wine</vocabulary>. It can also be called <vocabulary>plum wine</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>plum liquor</vocabulary>. If you're of age give it a taste, it's quite nice!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is just the readings of the kanji that you learned. How about a toast to easy to read words!

examples.en: Kristen is a professional negotiator.
examples.ja: クリステンは、交渉のプロです。

examples.en: I'll try negotiating, but please don't expect anything.
examples.ja: なんとか交渉してみますが、期待はしないでくださいね。

examples.en: We did it! The negotiations have concluded!
examples.ja: やりました！交渉が成立しましたよ！

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>ford</kanji> into the thick of things and <kanji>mix</kanji> everything up, you're getting involved in a <vocabulary>negotiation</vocabulary>. That's what negotiations are though, right? You gotta get right in there, fording through the muck. Then, you gotta mix things up and compromise between both parties.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Parents are helpless. When a child grows up, there is very little you can do for them.
examples.ja: 親は無力ですよ。子が大きくなると、してあげられることなんて、ほとんどありません。

examples.en: I was filled with a sense of shame as I realized how helpless I was.
examples.ja: 自分の無力さを知り、情けない気持ちでいっぱいになりました。

examples.en: There are too many things I can't do, and I feel incredibly powerless, but I'll do what I can today, no matter what.
examples.ja: できないことが多すぎて無力感がハンパないですが、とにかく今日できることをやっていきます。

meaning_mnemonic: When your <kanji>power</kanji> is <kanji>nothing</kanji> you are <vocabulary>powerless</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. There are a couple possibilities for 力 though, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember which to use: 

You know 力 uses its りょく reading here because you're totally <vocabulary>powerless</vocabulary> when they <reading>lock</reading> (りょく) you up. Who's "they"? I don't know, but did you hear the click of the lock behind you? That means you're powerless now.

examples.en: Koichi works without taking holidays.
examples.ja: コウイチは無休で働いている。

examples.en: Kanae and Mami are making WaniKani example sentences without any breaks.
examples.ja: カナエとマミは、無休でワニカニの例文を作っています。

examples.en: Tofugu’s website is always open, twenty-four hours a day, every day of the year.
examples.ja: トーフグのウェブサイトは、24時間年中無休で開いております。

meaning_mnemonic: If <kanji>rest</kanji> is <kanji>nothing</kanji> then there are <vocabulary>no holidays</vocabulary>. If there are no holidays, then that means a place is <vocabulary>always open</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>nonstop</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Fugu doesn’t want to die in anonymity.
examples.ja: フグは、無名のまま死にたくないと思っている。

examples.en: She's a big name, but she's also kind to unknown, new singers.
examples.ja: 彼女は大物だが、無名の新人歌手にも親切だ。

examples.en: Among young artists, there are many anonymous artists producing good work.
examples.ja: 若手のアーティストの中には、無名でも良い作品を作る人がたくさんいます。

meaning_mnemonic: Someone with "<kanji>nothing</kanji>" for their <kanji>name</kanji> is either trying to remain <vocabulary>anonymous</vocabulary> or is simply <vocabulary>unknown</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I am so glad that everyone is safe.
examples.ja: 皆さんが無事で本当に良かったです。

examples.en: I returned safely to the U.S.!
examples.ja: 無事にアメリカに帰国しました！

examples.en: This event has also ended without any problems!
examples.ja: 今回のイベントも、無事に終了いたしました！

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>nothing</kanji> <kanji>occurrence</kanji> is an occurrence where nothing happens to you, or at least nothing too bad — that means you're <vocabulary>safe and sound</vocabulary>. Phew! 

In addition to meaning <vocabulary>safe</vocabulary>, 無事 can also describe a situation where everything goes off <vocabulary>without a hitch</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: One thing that's not safe and sound is the reading of the 無 in this word. Instead of む it's ぶ. Why? Because you thought it was safe and sound, but you were fooled. There are ghosts everywhere, all jumping out and screaming <reading>Boo!</reading> (ぶ) at you. Feel the surprise. You thought it was safe and sound!

examples.en: This guy is way too ignorant.
examples.ja: コイツ、いくらなんでも無知すぎるだろ。

examples.en: Of course, I know this is an ignorant statement. But there are things that are good to say and things that are bad to say, right?
examples.ja: もちろん、無知による発言だってことは分かっています。でも、言って良いことと悪いことってありますよね？

examples.en: I'm worried people think of me as an ignorant know-it-all.
examples.ja: 周りの人から、無知なくせに知ったかぶりをするやつだと思われていたらどうしようと心配です。

meaning_mnemonic: When you <kanji>know</kanji> <kanji>nothing</kanji> (Jon Snow), you know nothing. This is <vocabulary>ignorance</vocabulary>, it's being <vocabulary>ignorant</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You didn't learn 知's on'yomi when you learned the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

What's the worst thing to live in <vocabulary>ignorance</vocabulary> of? Probably <reading>chee</reading>se (ち). Can you imagine not knowing cheddar from Swiss? Or gouda from brie? Imagine the sad, hollow life you would live if you were <vocabulary>ignorant</vocabulary> to the wonders of cheese.

examples.en: Don't say irrational things.
examples.ja: 無茶なこと言わないでよ。

examples.en: I think that idea is unreasonable.
examples.ja: そのアイデアは無茶だと思います。

examples.en: Don't be too reckless. Everyone is worried about you.
examples.ja: あんまり無茶ばっかりしないでね。みんな心配してるよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
Imagine having <kanji>nothing</kanji> but <kanji>tea</kanji> for an entire week. Sounds completely <vocabulary>irrational</vocabulary>, right? Such a <vocabulary>reckless</vocabulary> diet plan seems <vocabulary>excessive</vocabulary>.

無茶 is often used to point out that something goes against common sense; or to criticize or disapprove of some actions or situations that might be seen as reckless or excessive.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I like walking around eating free samples at Costco.
examples.ja: コストコで無料のサンプルを食べ歩くのが好きです。

examples.en: WaniKani is available for free until level three.
examples.ja: ワニカニは、レベル三まで無料で利用できます。

examples.en: This app can be downloaded for free.
examples.ja: このアプリは無料でダウンロードできます。

meaning_mnemonic: When the <kanji>fee</kanji> is <kanji>nothing</kanji> it is <vocabulary>free</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>without charge</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Do you have a pen that is a little finer?
examples.ja: もう少し細いペンはありますか？

examples.en: I think this thread is a bit too thin.
examples.ja: この糸はちょっと細すぎますね。

examples.en: Your fingers are slender and long like a pianist's.
examples.ja: ピアニストみたいに細くて長い指だね。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>thin</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>thin</vocabulary>, though it can be <vocabulary>slender</vocabulary> as well.
reading_mnemonic: If your garden is too <vocabulary>thin</vocabulary>, just get out the <reading>hose</reading> (ほそ)! How about if your hair is thin? Point the hose at your head! Hoses can cure any thin issues you may have.

examples.en: After all, he didn't pass the exam.
examples.ja: 結局、彼は試験に合格しませんでした。

examples.en: Speaking of which, what ended up happening with her?
examples.ja: そう言えば、彼女とは結局どうなったの？

examples.en: I went to buy some Valentine's chocolates for my friends, but in the end I only got some for myself.
examples.ja: バレンタインの友チョコを買いに行ったんだけど、結局自分用チョコしか買わなかったわ。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you <kanji>tie</kanji> the <kanji>bureau</kanji> up with your delays this may not get done this year <vocabulary>after all</vocabulary>.

This word carries the nuance that despite the various events or factors leading up to it, the final outcome just is what it is.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Note the けつ gets changed to けっ as つs in this situation often do.
