examples.en: Can I get your signature here, please?
examples.ja: ここに署名をお願いします。

examples.en: Our goal is to collect 10,000 signatures.
examples.ja: 一万人の署名を集めることが目標です。

examples.en: Please sign our online petition.
examples.ja: オンライン署名にご協力ください。

meaning_mnemonic: When you write your <kanji>name</kanji> for a <kanji>government office</kanji>, they require you to write out your <vocabulary>signature</vocabulary>. Printing won't do for official government office business.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: What is this medicine for?
examples.ja: これは何の薬ですか？

examples.en: I got the medicine at the pharmacy.
examples.ja: 薬屋さんで薬をもらってきました。

examples.en: His life is loaded up with drugs.
examples.ja: あの男は、薬づけの生活を送っている。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. If you're looking for medicine in Japan, look for this sign.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it should use the kun'yomi reading. When learning the kanji, you didn't learn that reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you with this word: You need some <vocabulary>medicine</vocabulary>, stat! But, nobody wants to give you any medicine. You keep asking your pharmacist, Yuri, if he'll give you some medicine. He says no. You get pissed off, and you <reading>cuss yuri</reading> (くすり) out. He gives you the medicine after you cuss him out.

examples.en: I want to get into the pharmacy department at this university.
examples.ja: 私はこの大学の薬学部に入りたいんです。

examples.en: He is a student of the pharmacy department at the University of Tokyo.
examples.ja: 彼は、東京大学の薬学部の学生です。

examples.en: That gentleman's son got a PhD in pharmaceutics.
examples.ja: あの方の息子さんは薬学でPhDを取られたそうです。

meaning_mnemonic: People who <kanji>study</kanji> about <kanji>medicine</kanji> are studying the <vocabulary>study of pharmacy</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Stop doing drugs right now!
examples.ja: 今すぐ薬物をやめろ！

examples.en: I heard that those yakuza are doing drug deals.
examples.ja: あのヤクザは薬物取引をしているそうだ。

examples.en: Apparently, that drug user is having hallucinations.
examples.ja: どうやらあの薬物使用者には幻覚が見えているらしい。

meaning_mnemonic:
These <kanji>medicine</kanji> <kanji>thing</kanji>s are of the bad kind, they're <vocabulary>drugs</vocabulary>!

As a standalone word, 薬物 generally refers to (often) illegal drugs that cause addiction or have a stimulating effect. Depending on the context, it can also refer to pharmaceutical drugs (aka <vocabulary>medicine</vocabulary>), but in that case, it's usually used in compounds like 薬物アレルギー (drug allergy).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I bought medicated lotion because it was on sale.
examples.ja: セールになってたから薬用ローションを買ってみました。

examples.en: I always use medicated soap.
examples.ja: 私はいつも薬用石けんを使っています。

examples.en: Does this pharmacy have medicinal lip moisturizers?
examples.ja: この薬局に、薬用リップクリームはありますか？

meaning_mnemonic: Something that's <kanji>use</kanji>d for <kanji>medicine</kanji> is <vocabulary>medicinal</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I have no sensation in my hands.
examples.ja: 手の感覚がありません。

examples.en: I like Tofugu's sense of humor.
examples.ja: トーフグのユーモアの感覚が好きです。

examples.en: I heard that deer have a very good sense of balance.
examples.ja: シカってすごくバランス感覚が良いんだって。

meaning_mnemonic: You know how we use <kanji>feeling</kanji>s to <kanji>memorize</kanji> things here on WaniKani? I ask you to feel angry or sad or happy while imagining out the mnemonic stories. I also ask you to use your <vocabulary>sense</vocabulary>s, because feelings are memorized best when you use <vocabulary>the senses</vocabulary>. This can also refer to any particular <vocabulary>sensation</vocabulary> or even somebody's <vocabulary>sense</vocabulary> of humor or fashion!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: He is not very good at explaining.
examples.ja: 彼は説明が下手です。

examples.en: Could you explain the rules of this board game?
examples.ja: このボードゲームのルールを説明してもらえますか？

examples.en: Please explain why you suddenly slowed down the train.
examples.ja: 電車のスピードを急に落とした理由を説明してください。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you make your <kanji>theory</kanji> <kanji>bright</kanji> (and clear and easy to understand) you must have come up with a great <vocabulary>explanation</vocabulary> for it. Before, it was dark and murky in everyone's mind. But, when you gave your explanation, it became bright and easy to understand! Yay!

説明 is a general, everyday word that is used when explaining something unknown or unfamiliar to make it understandable. You may see it when explaining how to use a device or describing a situation, for example.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: What is your favorite novel?
examples.ja: あなたの一番好きな小説は何ですか？

examples.en: I seriously love this novel. This is legit.
examples.ja: この小説マジで大好きだわ。これはホンモノだよ。

examples.en: Dad is glowing with pride because his novel is selling well, huh?
examples.ja: お父さん、小説が売れて鼻高々だね。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>small</kanji> <kanji>theory</kanji> is some idea you have that you put on paper. Perhaps it's an idea about life, that you write in the form of a <vocabulary>novel</vocabulary>?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: When you hear "a legendary Irish hero," who comes to mind?
examples.ja: アイルランドの伝説のヒーローと言えば、誰を思いうかべますか？

examples.en: Girls love you, man. You are legendary, seriously!
examples.ja: お前めちゃくちゃモテるな！マジで伝説的だよ。

examples.en: According to a legend, there is WaniKani in this ocean.
examples.ja: 伝説によると、この海にはワニカニが住んでいるそうです。

meaning_mnemonic: When people <kanji>transmit</kanji> a <kanji>theory</kanji> through the ages, it can turn into a <vocabulary>legend</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>legendary story</vocabulary>. Kind of like how the "theory" of King Arthur's sword turned into the legend of Excalibur.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You just have to remember that 伝 is read as でん in this case. Just imagine yourself sitting in your <reading>den</reading> (でん) as you get cozy and listen to this theory about a great <vocabulary>legend</vocabulary>.

examples.en: We started with the following hypothesis.
examples.ja: まずは次のような仮説を立てました。

examples.en: We need Koichi's help to prove that this hypothesis is correct.
examples.ja: この仮説が正しいことを立証するには、コウイチの力が必要です。

examples.en: If you want it to succeed, you have to be able to "fail." If you can't fail, you won't be able to test your hypothesis fast enough.
examples.ja: 成功させたいなら「失敗できる」ようにしておかないと。失敗できなくなると仮説をテストするスピードが落ちますよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>temporary</kanji> <kanji>theory</kanji> isn't one that's set in stone yet. In fact, it's not really a theory at all, it's more of a <vocabulary>hypothesis</vocabulary>.

This word is generally used when referring to research or some sort of investigation where a hypothesis is put forward that needs to be tested and validated through evidence and experimentation.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: This reference book comes with illustrations.
examples.ja: この参考書は図説付きです。

examples.en: Aya made an explanatory diagram of the in-house Tofugu relationships.
examples.ja: アヤが、トーフグ社内の人間関係の図説を作ってくれました。

examples.en: I think it would be easier to understand if there was an illustration with an explanation, what do you think?
examples.ja: もし説明と共に図説があれば、より分かりやすくなるかと思うんですが、どう思いますか？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>diagram</kanji> <kanji>theory</kanji> is an <vocabulary>illustration</vocabulary> that is used as an <vocabulary>explanatory diagram</vocabulary>. Just imagine a chalk board with all sorts of drawings of things, showing how they work, at least in theory.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: He knows only useless knowledge.
examples.ja: 彼は役に立たない知識ばかり知っています。

examples.en: Thank you for always providing useful knowledge.
examples.ja: いつもタメになる知識をありがとうございます。

examples.en: He managed to get through the situation with his existing knowledge.
examples.ja: 彼は持ち合わせの知識で何とかその場をしのいだ。

meaning_mnemonic: You're <kanji>discerning</kanji> about what you <kanji>know</kanji>. You choose what to keep and what not to keep in your brain. This is the sum of your <vocabulary>knowledge</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You didn't learn 知's on'yomi when you learned the kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

What's something you have a ton of <vocabulary>knowledge</vocabulary> about? <reading>Chee</reading>se (ち)! You have a massive, encyclopedic knowledge of all the world's cheeses. As a true bleu expert, it really grates on you that most other people's cheese knowledge is so full of holes.

examples.en: She lost consciousness.
examples.ja: 彼女は意識を失った。

examples.en: Is the person conscious, or unconscious?
examples.ja: その方は、意識はありますか？ありませんか？

examples.en: I read that broccoli is good for you, so I make a conscious effort to eat it.
examples.ja: ブロッコリーは体に良いと読んだので、意識して食べるようにしています。

examples.en: He's always studying and is quite aware, isn't he?
examples.ja: 彼っていつも勉強してるし、かなり意識が高いよね。

meaning_mnemonic:
Your <kanji>idea</kanji>s while <kanji>discerning</kanji> things show your <vocabulary>consciousness</vocabulary> and an <vocabulary>awareness</vocabulary> of your surroundings. You not only know that you have ideas, but you think about them and discern them.

意識 is often used in relation to whether someone has consciousness or not, like in medical contexts or news stories. In other contexts it can refer to being aware of certain things, like a high awareness of environmental issues.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: Don't move! It's the police.
examples.ja: 動くな！警察だ。

examples.en: I am sure the police will not help me.
examples.ja: きっと警察は助けてくれません。

examples.en: Maybe we should call the police?
examples.ja: 警察に電話した方がいいんじゃない？

meaning_mnemonic: They <kanji>warn</kanji> you and they <kanji>guess</kanji> when you've done something wrong (with evidence, of course!). They are the <vocabulary>police</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: I think this e-brake might be broken.
examples.ja: この非常ブレーキ、こわれてるかもしれないよ。

examples.en: The emergency alarm suddenly went off and I was surprised.
examples.ja: 急に非常ベルが鳴り出して、びっくりしました。

examples.en: Potato chips are a perfect emergency food.
examples.ja: ポテトチップスは非常食にピッタリです。

meaning_mnemonic:
When an <kanji>injustice</kanji> to what's <kanji>normal</kanji> is being committed, that makes it an <vocabulary>emergency</vocabulary>! 

Although it's less common, this can also be used as a な adjective. In that case, it means <vocabulary>extreme</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>unusual</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: The reindeer with the red nose over there is Rudolph.
examples.ja: あそこにいる鼻の赤いトナカイはルドルフです。

examples.en: He makes a loud noise when blowing his nose.
examples.ja: 彼は鼻をかむ音がうるさいです。

examples.en: Don't pick your nose!
examples.ja: 鼻クソをほじるな！

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji. Smells nice, right?

examples.en: Picking your nose with your fingers is unthinkable. Use Kleenex to clean it up.
examples.ja: 鼻くそ、指でほじるとかありえないんだけど。ティッシュ使って取りなよ。

examples.en: I felt nauseous after seeing a woman picking her nose and playing with her boogers on the train.
examples.ja: 電車で鼻くそをほじってこねてる女の人を見てしまい、気分が悪くなりました。

examples.en: After I scolded my three-year-old son for eating boogers and told him it was bad manners, he started saying "itadakimasu" before eating them.
examples.ja: 三才の息子が鼻くそを食べるので、「マナーが悪いよ！」と注意したら、食べる前に「いただきます」と言うようになりました。

meaning_mnemonic: If you're like everyone else learning a new language, you learn the bad words first. This isn't a bad word, but it sort of contains one. くそ means "sh*t" (as in "poop") in Japanese. What is your <kanji>nose</kanji> sh*t, then? It's your <vocabulary>snot</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>boogers</vocabulary>. Eww, stop eating them!
reading_mnemonic: The reading is just like what you learned with the kanji. <reading>はな</reading>くそ.

examples.en: You got mustard at the tip of your nose.
examples.ja: 鼻先にマスタードがついてるよ。

examples.en: This makeup incorporates tricks to make the nose appear higher.
examples.ja: このメイクは、鼻先を高く感じさせるトリックアートを取り入れています。

examples.en: That police dog started twitching the tip of its nose and sniffing at the stranger.
examples.ja: その警察犬は、鼻先をヒクヒクさせて、見知らぬ人のにおいをかぎ始めた。

meaning_mnemonic: You know the <kanji>previous</kanji> part of your <kanji>nose</kanji>? The part of your nose I just chopped off? Well, you were lucky, as that was only the <vocabulary>tip of the nose</vocabulary>. Time to cut off the rest, next!
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. With 鼻 you learned that with the kanji. With 先 you learned that with the vocab. So, you should have all the pieces to be able to read this. Remember, body parts tend to change words into kun'yomi readings for some reason, no exception here.

examples.en: Koichi was humming while making his nose swell.
examples.ja: コウイチは、鼻をふくらませながら、鼻歌を歌っていた。

examples.en: Viet was happily riding his bicycle while humming.
examples.ja: ビエトは鼻歌まじりで楽しそうに自転車に乗っていました。

examples.en: LMAO! You are just terrible at humming.
examples.ja: アハハ！お前鼻歌下手すぎだっつーの。

meaning_mnemonic: Try singing a <kanji>nose</kanji> <kanji>song</kanji>. How does it sound? Like <vocabulary>humming</vocabulary> perhaps?
reading_mnemonic: The readings are both kun'yomi vocab readings, probably because a 鼻 is a body part, and body parts do that to jukugo words. You know 鼻's reading from the kanji (はな) and you know 歌's reading from the vocabulary word 歌 (うた). Combine them together and you have a very nice humming tune and reading, はなうた.

examples.en: I often get nosebleeds.
examples.ja: 私は鼻血がよく出ます。

examples.en: I was surprised when I suddenly had a nosebleed.
examples.ja: 急に鼻血が出てきて、びっくりしました。

examples.en: I have a nosebleed, do you have any Kleenex?
examples.ja: 鼻血が出ちゃったんですが、ティッシュってありますか？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>nose</kanji> with <kanji>blood</kanji> is a nose with a <vocabulary>nosebleed</vocabulary>. It is a <vocabulary>bloody nose</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The readings are the kun'yomi vocab readings. You already know 鼻's reading from the kanji and vocab, and you should know the vocab reading of 血 as well. Put them together and you have はなち, though you want to change the ち to ぢ. Alternatively, it's possible (though less common, but it doesn't matter if you're turning it to kanji via an IME anyways) to write it as はなじ. I guess that blood added a little tenten (it represents the blood coming out of that nose!). Spurt spurt spurt.

examples.en: Certificates cannot be issued.
examples.ja: 証明書は発行できません。

examples.en: Could I check your ID?
examples.ja: 身分証明書はお持ちですか？

examples.en: I forgot my bag with my graduation certificate in it on the train.
examples.ja: 電車の中に卒業証明書が入ったカバンを忘れてきてしまった。

examples.en: Are you sure you own land on the moon? Do you have some sort of written proof?
examples.ja: あなたが月に土地を所有してるなんて本当なんですか？証明書でもあるんですか？

meaning_mnemonic:
Remember how 証明 means "proof"? Well, when you <kanji>write</kanji> the proof down on something, you have a <vocabulary>certificate</vocabulary>.

This can be used for different kinds of <vocabulary>written proof</vocabulary>, like a 卒業証明書 (graduation certificate), 身分証明書 (personal ID), and more.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Knowing 証明's reading will also be helpful.

examples.en: It is not possible to rewrite it now.
examples.ja: 今から書き直すのはムリです。

examples.en: Could you rewrite this part a bit?
examples.ja: この部分を少し書き直してもらえませんか？

examples.en: I rewrote that letter over and over again at the time.
examples.ja: その手紙、当時、何度も何度も書き直したんです。

meaning_mnemonic: 書く means "to write" and 直す means "to fix," right? Well, if you write something and then decide to fix it, you're going to have <vocabulary>to rewrite</vocabulary> it. Yup, the only way to fix that horrible chicken scratch paragraph you've written is to totally rewrite it from the ground up, so you'd better start rewriting ASAP.
reading_mnemonic: The readings come from 書く and 直す. Know those and you'll know how to read this word too!

examples.en: Where can I buy a sailor's uniform?
examples.ja: 水兵さんのセーラー服ってどこで買えるんですか？

examples.en: Do you know the song "The Seagull Sailor"?
examples.ja: 「かもめの水兵さん」っていう曲、知ってる？

examples.en: I happened to see the seaman saying something to the captain in a shaky voice.
examples.ja: あの水兵が、船長にふるえ声で何かを話しているのを見てしまったんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>water</kanji> <kanji>soldier</kanji> is a soldier that is out to sea. In other words, a <vocabulary>navy sailor</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

examples.en: You are quite the expert on mackerel sushi.
examples.ja: ずいぶんシメサバについて詳しいんですね。

examples.en: That person looks like they know a lot about computers.
examples.ja: あの人はコンピューターについて詳しそうだ。

examples.en: Wow! Really? Tell me everything.
examples.ja: おお、マジかよ？ 詳しく教えてくれよ。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>detailed</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>detailed</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: When something is <vocabulary>detailed</vocabulary> it is made up of a huge <reading>qua</reading>ntity (くわ) of little things. And if you're an <vocabulary>expert</vocabulary> on something, you'll have a huge quantity of knowledge, too.

examples.en: This user often sends us very detailed feedback.
examples.ja: このユーザーは、いつも詳細なフィードバックを送ってくれます。

examples.en: I don’t have enough time to look up the details.
examples.ja: 詳細を調べている時間がありません。

examples.en: I am not familiar with this topic and cannot comment on too many details.
examples.ja: このトピックについては詳しくないので、あまり詳細についてはコメントできません。

meaning_mnemonic: Things that are <kanji>detailed</kanji> and... <kanji>detailed</kanji> are, well, the <vocabulary>details</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Wanikani is a monster whose gender is unknown.
examples.ja: ワニカニは、性別不詳のモンスターです。

examples.en: My cousin's status is unknown because we almost never see each other.
examples.ja: イトコは、ほぼ会わないからステータスが不詳なんだよね。

examples.en: That person was shrouded in mystery, with their age and gender both unknown.
examples.ja: その人物は、年も性別も全てが不詳だった

meaning_mnemonic: Something is <kanji>not</kanji> <kanji>detailed</kanji> at all. I don't know anything about it. No details whatsoever. It's a totally <vocabulary>unknown</vocabulary> entity. It's <vocabulary>unidentified</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I heard there's a puppet show at the library at 3:00.
examples.ja: 図書館で三時から人形劇があるらしいよ。

examples.en: The person who plays the role of the horse in this play is my older brother.
examples.ja: この劇で馬の役をしているのがオレの兄なんだ。

examples.en: The person sitting behind me kept snapping his fingers during the play, which was very irritating.
examples.ja: 後ろの席の人が劇の最中にずっと指をポキポキ鳴らしてて、すっごくイライラしました。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well (<vocabulary>drama</vocabulary>). Can also mean <vocabulary>play</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>show</vocabulary> as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the kanji. No more drama from you, okay?

examples.en: I went to see the Yoshimoto New Comedy in Osaka.
examples.ja: 大阪でヨシモトの新喜劇を見てきました。

examples.en: There's a documentary about the comedy king Charlie Chaplin available on Netflix.
examples.ja: Netflixに喜劇王チャップリンのドキュメンタリーが上がってたよ。

examples.en: The movie is too sad. It should be called a tragedy, not a comedy.
examples.ja: その映画は悲しすぎて、喜劇というよりは悲劇だ。

meaning_mnemonic:
<kanji>Rejoice</kanji> <kanji>drama</kanji> isn't so much drama as it is <vocabulary>comedy</vocabulary>, since it makes you rejoice.

喜劇 is a relatively formal word that refers to comedy in a more traditional or stage-theater sense. For general comedies, people often say お笑い or コメディ.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: It was the beginning of my tragedy.
examples.ja: それが悲劇の始まりだった。

examples.en: This is indeed quite a tragic situation.
examples.ja: これはまたかなり悲劇的なシチュエーションですね。

examples.en: Are you trying to act like the heroine of some tragedy? Moping forever won't help anyone.
examples.ja: あんた、悲劇のヒロインにでもなったつもり？いつまでもクヨクヨしてたって仕方ないでしょ？

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>sad</kanji> <kanji>drama</kanji> always ends in <vocabulary>tragedy</vocabulary>. That's what makes it sad.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Today, I would like to share with you all a way to dramatically reduce your electricity bill.
examples.ja: 今日は皆さんに、電気代を劇的に安くする方法をお教えします。

examples.en: Frankly, a simple change in hairstyle can dramatically change one's appearance.
examples.ja: 正直、ヘアスタイルを変えるだけで、見た目は劇的に変わります。

examples.en: I love the show called "Dramatic Before and After".
examples.ja: 私は『劇的ビフォーアフター』という番組が大好きです。

meaning_mnemonic: Something that is <kanji>drama</kanji> <kanji>al</kanji> is <vocabulary>dramatic</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Let's meet up in the theater's lobby.
examples.ja: 劇場のロビーで待ち合わせしましょう。

examples.en: When will the film be released in theaters?
examples.ja: その映画の劇場公開はいつですか？

examples.en: We look forward to seeing you tomorrow at the theater.
examples.ja: それでは明日、劇場でお待ちしております。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>drama</kanji> <kanji>location</kanji> is where people do drama. This is a <vocabulary>theater</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Have you ever seen an opera?
examples.ja: 皆さんは歌劇を見たことがありますか？

examples.en: Where can I buy tickets for the opera?
examples.ja: 歌劇のチケットはどこで買えますか？

examples.en: I became a fan of a French actor in one of the operas.
examples.ja: 私はとある歌劇に出ていたフランス人役者のファンになりました。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>song</kanji> <kanji>drama</kanji>. Ugh, I hate these. They sing so much and they're so dramatic. This is an <vocabulary>opera</vocabulary>.

歌劇 is a formal word for opera that is typically used in theatrical or artistic contexts. In everyday speech, people usually just say オペラ.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: His handwriting is kind of bad, don't you think?
examples.ja: あの字はちょっと不味いんじゃない？

examples.en: Those sandwiches look a bit unappetizing, don't they?
examples.ja: なんか不味そうなサンドイッチだね。

examples.en: I have never had such a bad tasting avocado soup.
examples.ja: こんなに不味いアボカドスープを飲んだことはありません。

meaning_mnemonic: You've seen 美味しい by this point. This is the opposite of that. Instead of 美 you have 不 (not), so something that does <kanji>not</kanji> have <kanji>flavor</kanji> is something that doesn't taste good. i.e. something <vocabulary>bad tasting</vocabulary>. This can also refer to someone who's <vocabulary>unskillful</vocabulary> at something as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading doesn't follow any of the rules you've run into. It's まずい. Think about how you're going through this really long <reading>maze</reading> (まず) and how you're promised a really tasty wonderful treat at the end for getting through it (you're a lab rat or something). When you get to the end, there's your treat! What joy! You eat it and... oh man... it is so <vocabulary>bad tasting</vocabulary> you can't even believe it. Be sure to imagine the terrible taste and the terrible disappointment after going through that difficult maze only to get this... this... terribly <vocabulary>unappetizing</vocabulary> cheese.

examples.en: American soldiers often gave us gum and chocolate.
examples.ja: アメリカ兵からよくガムやチョコレートをもらいました。

examples.en: In this war, it seems that robot soldiers, not humans, will be fighting.
examples.ja: 今回の戦争では、人間ではなくロボット兵が戦っているようです。

examples.en: Apparently, many of the soldiers who ate the meat became ill with food poisoning.
examples.ja: その肉を食べた多くの兵が、食中毒になってしまったそうです。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: It is absolutely impossible.
examples.ja: ゼッタイ無理です。

examples.en: Please don't be too unreasonable.
examples.ja: あんまり無理なことばかり言わないでください。

examples.en: Don't overdo it. Take care of yourself, too.
examples.ja: 無理しすぎないで、自分の体も大事にしてね。

meaning_mnemonic: If you can do <kanji>nothing</kanji> within <kanji>reason</kanji>, then what you're trying to do is <vocabulary>unreasonable</vocabulary> and probably downright <vocabulary>impossible</vocabulary>. If you still try, you're probably just <vocabulary>overdoing</vocabulary> it.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. As long as you know the readings for these kanji, you should be able to read this word just fine.

examples.en: Can I stay by your side a little longer?
examples.ja: もう少しだけ、側にいてもいい？

examples.en: Don't leave mom's side, okay?
examples.ja: お母さんの側をはなれちゃダメだよ！

examples.en: I'm thinking of putting a cactus next to the sofa.
examples.ja: ソファの側にサボテンがほしいなと思ってるの。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic:
You've learned the <reading>がわ</reading> as the reading for this kanji, but when its used on its own as a vocabulary word, it is read as <reading>そば</reading>. Here's a mnemonic to help you remember:

Having a <reading>sober</reading>(そば) person by your <vocabulary>side</vocabulary> is important when you're drunk. 

Think of other vocabulary words that use <reading>がわ</reading>. In these words, <kanji>側</kanji> is a suffix, so it will have another kanji that comes before it.

examples.en: I cannot trust that man because he changes his opinions so often.
examples.ja: あの男は意見がコロコロ変わるので信用できません。

examples.en: People's ways of thinking change over time, don't they?
examples.ja: 人の考え方は時間とともに変わるものでしょ？

examples.en: Advances in AI have changed the way work is done.
examples.ja: AIの進歩により、仕事のやり方が大きく変わりました。

meaning_mnemonic:
You've seen how 変える means "to change" something. This word means that something changed by itself, so it means <vocabulary>to be changed</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to be altered</vocabulary>.

変わる refers to the act of changing into something different, and involves alterations in nature, appearance, or state. For example, it can describe changes in weather or the season, someone undergoing a noticeable change in appearance or behavior, or one's feelings or thoughts evolving over time.

Since 変わる means "becoming something different," you can also use 変わった and 変わっている to describe someone or something that's "different from what's normal." For example, you can say 変わった人 or 変わっている人 to mean "an odd person."
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

examples.en: These grapes are seedless, so they are easy to eat.
examples.ja: このブドウはタネ無しだから食べやすいですよ。

examples.en: Please, no last-minute cancellations, okay?
examples.ja: ドタキャンは無しでお願いしますね！

examples.en: I'm broke, jobless, and am an unattractive guy in my forties. Why would you want to be with someone like me?
examples.ja: オレ、金無し、仕事無し、ブサメンの四十代だぜ。なんでオレなんかと付き合いたいの？

meaning_mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>nothing</kanji>, so when you have nothing, you are <vocabulary>without</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

When you are <vocabulary>without</vocabulary> you don't have anything to eat either, so you end up <reading>gnashi</reading>ng (なし) your teeth together instead.

examples.en: This manga hasn’t been completed yet.
examples.ja: このマンガはまだ完結していません。

examples.en: I wrote a spin-off of the story after the series was completed.
examples.ja: シリーズ完結後の話をスピンオフとして書きました。

examples.en: This novel will be concluded in the next edition.
examples.ja: この小説は、次号で完結する予定です。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>perfect</kanji> way to <kanji>tie</kanji> up a research paper is with a <vocabulary>conclusion</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Every night I get a silent prank phone call.
examples.ja: 毎晩無言電話がかかってくるんです。

examples.en: He left the room without saying a word.
examples.ja: 彼は無言のまま部屋を出て行った。

examples.en: Tofugu workers seem to work silently, but they are actually chatting on an app called Slack.
examples.ja: トーフグの社員たちは、無言で仕事をしているように見えますが、実はスラックというアプリでチャットしています。

meaning_mnemonic: When you have <kanji>nothing</kanji> to <kanji>say</kanji> you sit in <vocabulary>silence</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You didn't learn this reading for 言 though, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Nothing cuts through <vocabulary>silence</vocabulary> like a <reading>gon</reading>g (ごん). Once it's done gonging you really notice how silent the world around you is.

examples.en: That vampire has been waiting for the one he loves for 6000 years.
examples.ja: あのバンパイアは6000年も愛する人のことを待っている。

examples.en: Do you love me?
examples.ja: 私のこと、愛してる？

examples.en: Koichi loves Tofugu very much and often murmurs things like, "Oh my dear Tofugu-chan."
examples.ja: コウイチはトーフグのことをとても愛していて、よく「僕の愛するトーフグちゃん」とつぶやいています。

meaning_mnemonic: You know that 愛 means <kanji>love</kanji>. So, when you add する to it you make it a verb. Now it means <vocabulary>to love</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

examples.en: As usual, you're doing something interesting.
examples.ja: 相変わらず面白いことをしてるね。

examples.en: He was muttering an oath under his breath as usual.
examples.ja: 彼は相変わらず、つぶやくような小声で、ヒドイことを言いまくっていた。

examples.en: Mr. Cow, as usual, you've got a cool nose ring, but I can see your nose hairs today.
examples.ja: 牛さん、相変わらずかっこいい鼻輪をつけてるね。でも、今日は鼻毛が出てるよ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>mutual</kanji> <kanji>change</kanji> you make with other people will go so smoothly that it will seem like everything is working <vocabulary>as usual</vocabulary>. It will be like everything is <vocabulary>the same</vocabulary> as it was before because the change was mutual.
reading_mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: You couldn’t even be his lover!
examples.ja: お前は愛人にすらなれなかったんだよ。

examples.en: I was told I looked like a mistress, which really pissed me off.
examples.ja: 愛人っぽい顔してるねって言われて、すごくムカつきました。

examples.en: I'm going to have dinner at my mistress's house today, so I don't need dinner.
examples.ja: 今日は愛人の家でご飯食べてくるから、晩ご飯はいらないよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>person</kanji> you make <kanji>love</kanji> to is your <vocabulary>lover</vocabulary>. Woooh! Don't worry I won't tell. Have fun and be safe, kids.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Life could end at any moment, so we have to take good care of it.
examples.ja: いつ果てるともしれない命なんだから、大切にしないと。

examples.en: I thought, I must not die here.
examples.ja: こんなところで果てるワケにはいかないと思ったんです。

examples.en: Japanese salarymen are all exhausted.
examples.ja: 日本のサラリーマンは、みんなくたびれ果てています。

meaning_mnemonic: If you tear (てる) up a <kanji>fruit</kanji>, its life is going <vocabulary>to end</vocabulary>. In other words, the poor thing is going <vocabulary>to die</vocabulary>. Fruit can't go on when they've been beaten up so much.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

The fruit's life is about <vocabulary>to end</vocabulary> and you laugh, "<reading>Ha</reading>hahaha (は)!" And then you start tearing at it more! What's wrong with you? Weirdo...

examples.en: It’s beef stew that’s full of love.
examples.ja: 愛情たっぷりのビーフシチューです。

examples.en: I have never felt the love of my parents.
examples.ja: 私は両親の愛情を感じたことがありません。

examples.en: I'm not short of love, I'm short of money. I don't need affection, I need money.
examples.ja: 愛情不足じゃなくて金欠なんです。愛情なんかいらないから、お金をください。

meaning_mnemonic: Those <kanji>love</kanji> <kanji>feeling</kanji>s you're having mean you're in <vocabulary>love</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I have had a fever since the day before yesterday.
examples.ja: 一昨日から熱が出ています。

examples.en: I woke up early the day before yesterday and went jogging.
examples.ja: 一昨日の朝は、早起きしてジョギングに行きました。

examples.en: The night before last, I was able to see a beautiful starry sky.
examples.ja: 一昨日の夜は、美しい星空を見ることができました。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how you learned that 昨日 means "yesterday?" Well <kanji>one</kanji> day <kanji>previous</kanji> to that <kanji>day</kanji> is the <vocabulary>day before last</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
This reading is an exception. Let's use this mnemonic to remember it:

The <vocabulary>day before last</vocabulary> you bought an <reading>"O" toe toy</reading> (おととい). It's a kid's toy in the shape of the letter O that you put on your toe. You know it was the day before last because you wore it all yesterday, and now today your toe is sore. If only you could go back to the <vocabulary>day before yesterday</vocabulary> to tell yourself not to buy that O toe toy! Or at least not to wear it for the whole next day!

examples.en: This is a photo that captures the springtime of my life.
examples.ja: これは青春時代の思い出の写真です。

examples.en: It's just like a page out of our youth!
examples.ja: まさに青春の１ページって感じだね！

examples.en: Emi, you're fully relishing your youth!
examples.ja: エミ、めっちゃ青春してるじゃん！

meaning_mnemonic:
The time of <kanji>young</kanji> <kanji>spring</kanji> for humans is really just their <vocabulary>youth</vocabulary>. Just like plants in spring, your <vocabulary>adolescence</vocabulary> is when you start growing to your full potential! You might even say it's <vocabulary>the springtime of one's life</vocabulary>.

This generally refers to the period when you’re an energetic teenager and young adult. It can have connotations of exhilarating experiences and bittersweet feelings, as well as nostalgic memories.
reading_mnemonic:
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned the on'yomi for 春 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Don't let your <vocabulary>youth</vocabulary> go to waste, because it will be over <reading>soon</reading> (しゅん)!

examples.en: How did you become fluent in Japanese?
examples.ja: どうやって日本語ペラペラになったの？

examples.en: Ah, I want to be able to speak English fluently soon.
examples.ja: あー、はやく英語がペラペラ話せるようになりたい。

examples.en: Hey, you've been blabbing on and on! We're in the library, remember?
examples.ja: ねえ、さっきから、ペラペラペラペラうるさいよ！ここ、図書館だよ？

meaning_mnemonic:
<reading>Parrot, parrot</reading> (ペラペラ), your speaking is so <vocabulary>fluent</vocabulary>!

ペラペラ is an オノマトペ that describes someone speaking a language fluently, or simply being a real chatterbox.

Related to this, ペラペラ also means <vocabulary>leafing through a book</vocabulary>. And in an extension of that meaning, it can describe something <vocabulary>paper thin</vocabulary> or flimsy, like a piece of paper from that book you're leafing through.

examples.en: It seems that he injured his head while playing soccer.
examples.ja: 彼は、サッカーで頭部にケガをしたようです。

examples.en: However, it seems that there was no issue with his head X-ray.
examples.ja: でも、頭部のレントゲンに問題はなかったそうです。

examples.en: That guy deliberately aimed for your head!
examples.ja: アイツ、わざとお前の頭部をねらったんだよ！

meaning_mnemonic:
Your <kanji>head</kanji> <kanji>part</kanji>, or the part of your body that's your head, is… well, your <vocabulary>head</vocabulary>!

This is a more formal way of saying "head" compared to just 頭, so you'll encounter this more frequently in medical and other, more formal contexts.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You haven't learned this reading for 頭 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Need a checkup on your head? Then head to とうきょう! They have the best… head doctors in とうきょう, I've heard. So head on over to とうきょう for your next head checkup.
